developerResponse: {'id': 26881805, 'body': "Thanks so much for your review! We're so happy to hear you met someone special in the Hive! We'd love to learn more about your story. Please share it with us at bumble.com/success. We can't wait to read all about it!", 'modified': '2021-12-16T21:14:58Z'}
review: I completely loved this app. I haven‚Äôt ever used dating apps and about a year ago I decided to give them a try. I did some research and decided to try Bumble first as I was looking for something serious. The app is really easy to use, I just wished the chat window was a bit more interactive and allowed to delete messages (lol), but again the purpose of this app is just to use it as a first step and continue chatting/texting out of it once you think you have a match. As a woman, is nice to be able to take the first step to initiate the conversation. I had 3 dates with really nice guys before finding my current boyfriend (we‚Äôll soon be celebrating our first anniversary!), so we are both very happy we found each other with this app. The only thing I would recommend them to change is to allow choosing pictures from your phone instead of Facebook. I met one guy who had old photos on Facebook because he just didn‚Äôt interact with it a lot, so when we met in person he looked a bit different. Overall it was a good app, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for something serious, guys here were really nice, some really well educated, and a couple were absolute gentleman.
title: Great app for those looking for something serious

developerResponse: {'id': 33604396, 'body': "Thanks for reaching out, HonestBudthegreat. While our subscriptions are there to help maximize your experience, we can't promise exact results for anyone. If you‚Äôd like to talk to a Support Team Member about your profile to check everything is running as it should be, please message us here: bumble.com/contact.", 'modified': '2022-12-08T07:51:44Z'}
review: This app is set up like all the rest. Swipe left or right. You can‚Äôt search everyone at once, you have to go through 1 at a time and eventually you won‚Äôt be able to swipe right anymore till you pay or wait a day under the bumble guise of ‚Äúlimited free right swipes make you think harder about who you swipe right on‚Äù but once you pony up the cash, swipe right all you want. Here‚Äôs where the con comes in. Once you sign up you‚Äôll get 10 +/- likes which of course you can‚Äôt see till you pay. Then you pay and if none of those likes are you‚Äôre type you can pay more to promote your profile or pay more to super like someone. Oh and eventually you‚Äôll run out of people who fit your search criteria. I live between two major cities with a population of over 8 million people, my criteria was women within 20 years of my age. I ran out of people to look at after 2 days‚Ä¶..but wait, the day after my subscription ran out I received a bunch more likes on my profile.  Which of course then you have to again to see those likes.  Coincidence? I am convinced your is not shown until maybe the last day of your subscription in order to get you to resubscribe.  I understand this is a business and the route to make money. But it‚Äôs pretty ridiculous when it‚Äôs that obvious.  Oh and by the way when you run out of people that fit your criteria, log back in 15 mins later, there‚Äôs another 25 people to search till you run out again.
title: A good con

review: I‚Äôve been using Bumble a year, I‚Äôve met one person. The service is terrible. The ads are filled with people promoting social media, but they don‚Äôt appear to be filtered. Men constantly post as women, it gets old. A new feature came out called compliments. I had a total of four women respond, and I received a notification I received a message. How ever, there is no message, it‚Äôs literally opening up an email with a subject and no message. Support will claim they blocked me, were banned or deleted their profile, but I can still see their profile. It doesn‚Äôt ad up, as anyone knows of any of those three criteria are met, you can no longer see that users profile. One customer rep told me it was a glitch, when I replied back they send what appears to be a copy and paste reply and ignore basically the issue you‚Äôre having. They will tell you there‚Äôs more users joining, your profile is working and keep trying. You then have to email them again. I‚Äôve sent several message and I have not received any replies, it appears they have turned off my support function for sending multiple messages on a time sensitive issue that they deny exists. Even if you buy super swipes, if a free user can only swipe so many people, what good is your swipe? I feel the app would be better if it wasn‚Äôt for the pricey ads on, better moderation of fake profiles or real profiles with the intent of just promoting social media. While we continue to work hard to improve this, if we can help your experience further right now, please send us a message at bumble.com/contact. üíõ", 'modified': '2023-01-18T15:57:45Z'}
review:
I usually only get a dozen or so right swipes each day and after my few minutes of free swiping are up I get this annoying message asking me to subscribe to get more swipes. That being said, the user interface is good and I‚Äôve had good experiences with people I‚Äôve met here, I just wish there was more consideration for people like me who don‚Äôt feel like paying big bucks each month to keep on swiping.

The developer left a response where they reminded me that I get new swipes every 24 hours, encouraging me to reach out to support if my swipes are not resetting and I appreciate the response. That 24-hour reset is a big part of the problem, I feel almost compelled to make a few obligatory swipes each day, because if I take a break from the app then I‚Äôll spend a few weeks where I constantly run out of swipes and get limited on the number of matches I can make. Another surprising this here is that the subscription is much more expensive than Tinder‚Äôs top-tier subscription and yet Tinder has vastly more people than Bumble. (Tinder also gives me way more free swipes than Bumble does).

In short, I do like this app but it feels like a chore that I need to check off each day and my bumper of matches gets artificially limited because I‚Äôm not interested in paying for an expensive subscription.
title: ‚ÄúOut of likes for today‚Äù, freemium software: update after dev response

review: This app is good for meeting new people, however, it‚Äôs kinda unfair to use. What I mean by this is that if you end up liking someone or someone (or that person) likes you, in order for you to see who that is or for it to be an official match, you must pay $18 just to see who they are that liked you, which is really unnecessary and expensive if all you‚Äôre trying to do is meet someone, and god forbid it‚Äôs someone you don‚Äôt find interesting or doesn‚Äôt match your personality, then you‚Äôd end up just blowing $18 for no reason when the whole point was just to meet someone YOU thought was perfect for you. And on top of that, the women have to make the first move (which isn‚Äôt necessarily a bad thing), but some don‚Äôt make a move at all after matching (from what I experienced). So it then makes it unclear as to whether they even meant to do that in the first place or not, and since I (a male) can‚Äôt say anything first, I‚Äôm just left in the dark as to why I haven‚Äôt heard from anyone cause I can‚Äôt say anything to confirm if she‚Äôs willing to meet. Im not trying to complain or say it‚Äôs a bad app or anything cause it actually does what it‚Äôs supposed to do, but I‚Äôm just pointing out the flaws of paying an expensive price just to see who swiped you and whether it was worth the money or not and also pointing out the communication issues between people.
title: Not bad, but needs work

review: I don‚Äôt use the apps much but during Covid and for travels to meet People I opened it. If you‚Äôre looking to meet people  and go on dates this is not for you sorry. Better bet would be badoo. Maybe i haven‚Äôt had it for long enough but the guys here while they will answer and I had a lot of matches expect the girl to do all the work not just with writing them first but the whole time. Meanwhile from other apps I‚Äôve actually met up with guys and met interesting   ones from other countries. While the guys here are attractive and accomplished it doesn‚Äôt do much when I already have dates lined up from other apps that have maybe more choices but guys that aren‚Äôt as appealing. I refuse to pay to use any of these apps, just wanted to see how it goes. I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs great guys on here but they need to realize girls can get lots of messages and offers and they should act fast instead of waiting around for the girl to propose something . I‚Äôm old fashioned and like that Guys here don‚Äôt say inappropriate things and there are a lot of quality guys. But when you hear the same ones have been on it forever maybe it‚Äôs because you guys put zero effort into it. I even put my Instagram account in my profile so guys can contact me there and I‚Äôm open to meet and respond to my matches. It makes me wonder why guys even have these apps on their phones

review: I have been a Bumble user for quite sometime now. The site is decent aside from the forced pop-ups asking for contributions and ‚Äúsocial causes.‚Äù I recently was looking into a subscription for the site and had the incorrect one applied to my account. My first inquiry for assistance was closed without any response and when I tried to follow up they said the matter was resolved and they wouldn‚Äôt response to my email. When I opened a second case, although I shouldn‚Äôt have had to in the first place, I received a general response with absolutely no details or personal reflection of my inquiry simply telling me I can purchase the additional subscription for the additional cost, which wasn‚Äôt even what I was inquiring about in the first place. You‚Äôd think for a site that prides itself on its users and highlights a CEO who makes billions of the site, the customer service would be somewhat adequate to answer the concerns of the users in a timely manner. However that is far from the reality of this app and it‚Äôs customer service. Would highly recommend staying away from this app and using one of the competitors, they are better sites anyway. developerResponse: {'id': 23558123, 'body': "Thanks for letting us know of your experience, Sebastian. Do you mind sending us a message at http://bumble.com/contact?", 'modified': '2021-06-24T06:37:29Z'}
review: Not a bad app. Haven‚Äôt gotten any targeted ads yet, and haven‚Äôt been smothered with obvious fakes either. I‚Äôm giving the lower rating because they have basically put the ‚ÄúDealbreaker‚Äù buttons in your range settings as a placebo. I‚Äôve been trying to go mile-by-mile outward, because there is an entire college just outside of 40 miles away, and my queue will be entirely dominated by people from that college if I don‚Äôt restrict my range. What I find happening anyway is I will still see people OUTSIDE that range after I‚Äôve set my range to be a dealbreaker! Even sneakier, I will sometimes find that this setting has been turned off for me, as if they‚Äôre trying to pull a fast one on me. In addition, how is it that one day I can swipe through every profile in a specific range, but the next day there‚Äôs several less than 10 miles out? Not likely they made their profile day, since that little ‚Äúnew here‚Äù bubble appears on their profile. There is clearly some sneaky business going on to restrict your swiping to people who will never see your profile past a certain point, and hold some in reserve so you can swipe on for longer. In the end, however, these practices are less predatory than most of your other options for dating apps. If you‚Äôre dead set on picking on, this is probably your best bet.
title: Deceptive with your matching preferences.

developerResponse: {'id': 30629887, 'body': 'We‚Äôre thrilled you made such a special connection in the Hive! Please tell us more about your story at bumble.com/success. üíõ', 'modified': '2022-06-29T22:38:36Z'}
review:
bumble was my last shot at finding someone who was looking for the same kind of relationship as me. I was looking for something long term, and none of the other apps I tried seemed to have an option for that. With bumble, not only was this an option, but I found my perfect match. Every day I‚Äôm grateful that bumble exists for this reason. I do not have the app anymore for obvious reasons, but I recommend it highly to anyone who is looking to find a real, loving and healthy relationship. Most dating apps are set up for hookups and such. With bumble this is not the case if you don‚Äôt want it to be. I love the idea of the girl talking first too. As a girl, this does make things a little awkward, but it helps to be the one making the first move. As in other dating apps, guys typically hit girls with pickup lines or flat out ask if they want to hook up. I felt like I could explain what I was looking for so much easier with bumble. My personal trainer had recommended it to me after he found his now wife on the app. I‚Äôm so glad he told me about it. Me and my boyfriend have been together for 8 months now, and are planning on a long happy future together. 

Thank you bumble, from the bottom of my heartüíõ
title: thank you bumbleüíõ

review:
I don‚Äôt know what it is about Bumble- if it‚Äôs the fact that women start the conversation, causing them to use it less, or a lack of use relative to other dating apps, or the algorithm for non-paying users- but in the month I have had it I haven‚Äôt had a single match. And I‚Äôm not saying this as a bummed out nerd who is taking their lack of female attention out on the app itself; I use just about every other dating platform and get consistent likes/matches. It makes me think that users who don‚Äôt pay suffer when it comes to views, but I‚Äôm not willing to pay the INSANE amount of money they are asking to test that theory. 
They could easily offer a lower tier of premium with the use of ad revenue, rather than banking that users will pay the exorbitant amount of money required to get your profile out there - and that goes for all dating apps. 
This no doubt causes users to lose faith in the app, or the process in general, and it‚Äôs not a sustainable business model. 
It‚Äôs a bummer, too, I honestly like the idea of women starting the conversation and I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs a welcome breath of fresh air for them, not constantly being bombarded by creepy dudes all day long. I also like the profile structure (apart from the MEGA cheesy prompt selection). Maybe one day I‚Äôll try paying for a month to see if that makes a difference, but for the time being, Hinge and Tinder seem to be working ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

review: If I could give this 0 stars (or less) I would! It looks great on paper, until you have a problem. I had been having problems with the amount of likes I was getting from the free membership. I put in a ticket to ask how many likes I should have and explained the situation. They responded saying I should have 30 likes per 24 hours and that I‚Äôve used mine for today (it had been a week since I had any likes). I then tried to explain again and was ghosted. For a couple weeks I was trying to get in touch with them about my ticket with no response. I then opened another ticket to ask for help again. They didn‚Äôt even acknowledge this one. Today (about 2 months later) I got an email saying they hadn‚Äôt heard from me so they were closing me ticket‚Ä¶ I responded saying that they should have heard from me in this ticket AND another one. I had deleted my app at this point due to the frustration and sour taste left because of support. They then sent an automatic response email, which made it even more obvious they never read my email today OR any of the emails before. review: I‚Äôve been on and off Bumble for a few years now and it has really gone downhill over the years. First things first, Premium has gone up in price. I remember premium was like $20 a month or so, then it went to $30, $35, to now $50!!! It is way too overpriced and not really that beneficial, why would I want to pay $50 just to see who likes me only for them to to not talk to me, or they‚Äôre 50 miles away when I have my preference to 20 miles!! Also they say that premium profiles get shown more but I highly doubt it because I‚Äôm usually on the app everyday swiping, and have maybe only gotten one like within the span of about every two weeks!! Premium is not worth the $50, especially since it seems like a lot of women are only using the app to promote their Instagram/Onlyfans. I don‚Äôt think this is Bumble‚Äôs fault at all, but I can‚Äôt justify spending $50 just be targeted by someone who‚Äôs not looking for a relationship, and only looking for my credit card number. I think this is my last time using Bumble. It stinks because I have been successful in the past with matches and going on dates, but it seems that this app is just getting greedy and getting ruined by opportunists. If you want to go on dates and actually find something meaningful, go on Hinge or Coffee Meets Bagel, I‚Äôve had better luck recently on those apps. Or, if you want to skip the hassle, just pay for eHarmony/Match.
title: Gone Downhill Over the Years

developerResponse: {'id': 28986426, 'body': 'We‚Äôre really glad you spoke up about this. We deeply value inclusion and want everyone to feel welcome and supported at all times. Your voice has been heard and while we continue to work hard to improve this, if we can help your experience further right now, please send us a message at bumble.com/contact. üíõ', 'modified': '2022-04-05T20:49:37Z'}
review: This app is overall okay. I like that they have a lot of options on things you can add to your profile, but their monthly price is really high. $40 for basically one month, and $20 for a week, just so you can see people who have swiped on you or even to just filter things such as height preference. But what really gets me here, is the way they handle gender identity and how they categorize it. I‚Äôm a trans male, who‚Äôs interested in women, and I‚Äôve had no problems in my past with dating women. But if I change my gender identity to ‚Äútrans man‚Äù on this app and set my preference as ‚Äúwomen‚Äù my feed is changed to nothing but other women who are interested in women, or people looking for ‚Äúpoly‚Äù relationships. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm quite what lesbians are looking for bumble? But once I set my gender back to ‚Äúmale‚Äù I‚Äôm brought back to women who are interested in men. So I have no choice but to just put ‚Äúmale‚Äù and then that I‚Äôm ‚Äútrans‚Äù in my bio. So maybe something needs to be changed about that? Why should I feel that I‚Äôm less of a man on this app? I get that you try and pair ‚Äúlgbtq+‚Äù with others in that same category, but make it make sense. If I say I‚Äôm ‚Äústraight‚Äù I should only be seeing what my preference is. If others choose to not like me because I‚Äôm trans, let them make that decision.
title: Gender settings are nice, but a bit weird.

review: So Bumble definitely shadowbans or at least outright blocks you. I had Bumble for about 2 years straight. One of the women I met off there ended up stalking me and I deleted the account out of fear she would create fake profiles and try to monitor me. Needless to say I ended up moving for work and decided to make another account now that I felt safe. Within the first hour I had several likes, however, that stopped instantly after that. Nothing after that first hour (I live in a large metropolitan area so this is unusual). I‚Äôm also not an ugly guy by any means. It‚Äôs not difficult to see who likes your profile since bumble‚Äôs blurred image for your queue is easily distinguishable when swiping. I noticed that one particular like I had showed up in my stack and I didn‚Äôt swipe on it initially. I reopened the app later to see my likes disappear. HOWEVER, these profiles still showed up in the stack and they are unable to unlike your profile once they‚Äôve swiped right. This happened with almost all of the likes I had and they weren‚Äôt bot profiles. I received no more likes since that first hour and I kept the app for a week and a half to make sure. Pretty pathetic I received whatever ‚Äúban‚Äù they clearly have in place simply because I deleted my account to protect myself. Not like I‚Äôm deleting and recreating the app every other week. Won‚Äôt be recommending or using (like I could anyway) this app again.
title: Bumble Ban

review:
There‚Äôs an individual on here who does work in my neighborhood and has come onto me in a way that made me highly uncomfortable. He leers at me every time he‚Äôs around. I have blocked him on bumble only to see he has popped up since I blocked him about 7 more times!!!!!!!    
In addition to this, in June I sent a Twitter DM to inquire about the free boost trial. They told me they were having issues with boost and they would manually apply it to my account. I had about 1,000 profiles to scroll through and I had gotten through about 25 and without changing any preferences, while I was in the middle of looking at the bumble Match Queue, my ENTIRE queue disappeared! There were a few accounts I saved to look at better later and hundreds I hadn‚Äôt even seen that disappeared in a flash. I wrote them on Twitter and the bumble rep was less than helpful and it got to the point where they were just rude. Later I told them I wanted the boost removed from my account completely but was told they cannot do that. 
Since the time Boost was manually applied by them it rendered that whole match queue area useless. The trial has expired; it never worked anyway, but now even the blurred out profiles are gone. I‚Äôll have guys who ‚Äúsuper like‚Äù me that don‚Äôt show up in the queue as blurred out profiles.

Bumble used to be a good app. The boost thing was just an annoyance but now that I feel unsafe with the block feature not working, I had to write a review and disable my account.
title: Feel Unsafe

review:
I joined bumble only a couple weeks ago and had 4 maybe 5 liked by others, but they weren‚Äôt mutual so I never saw who they were. I shouldn‚Äôt have to pay money just to meet someone. I get that bumble is being the middle man in the possible relationship but that‚Äôs what gets me. It‚Äôs a ‚Äúpossible‚Äù relationship. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôll work out or not why should I pay 40 dollars just to see someone‚Äôs profile that may or may not be close to me at all! It‚Äôs a joke and a scam. If you wanted to help people meet other people why make them pay for it? Why couldn‚Äôt you just put ads in from sponsors like you do for push notifications? That gives you money doesn‚Äôt it? Or an actual 10 second ad after so many skips then give the option for a one time purchase to stop the ads. I don‚Äôt see why I need to pay what was it 20-40 dollars for a week!?! Absolutely ridiculous what a waste of time.
If you read to this point believe me it‚Äôs just like every other dating app asking for money to see someone. It‚Äôs disappointing. Oh and there‚Äôs bots as well so you if you choose to subscribe to them you may be losing money to talk to someone trying to scam you.

I would go back to bumble if the paywall wasn‚Äôt there or if it was a one time purchase. So to the bumble team, Ik you won‚Äôt, but as a friendly suggestion take that into consideration and good luck.
title: Takes too long to get a mutual match and a paywall

developerResponse: {'id': 27930497, 'body': "Hi there! Thanks for sharing your thoughts with us. We know our users are busy so all of our members have the opportunity to extend one match for an additional 24 hours. You can also extend unlimited matches with Bumble Boost and Bumble Premium! To make sure you don't miss any matches, head to your in-app settings to turn on your notifications. We appreciate you sharing your feedback with us. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience on the app so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team. üíõ", 'modified': '2022-02-08T22:41:40Z'}
review: I think all dating apps has its pros and cons but what Bumble lacks is putting it behind apps like Tinder (I hate to even compare it to Tinder) and Hinge. For example, Tinder at least has the feature where you can search numbers through your contact list and block them from seeing your profile in the app. I wish Bumble had a similar feature because you do see a lot of the same user profiles in most of the dating apps and I‚Äôd like to be able to block someone that I didn‚Äôt necessarily connect well with or from having a family member or coworker see my profile. Also the 24 hour match feature where the woman has to message the guy first and wait for him to respond during that time or else the match completely disappear is just not right. I sometimes go days without checking the app because I‚Äôm busy with work and life in general or choose to take mental breaks, before logging back on and then finding my ‚Äúmatch‚Äù has disappeared. I‚Äôve lost many potential matches this way or some that I‚Äôve messaged and they don‚Äôt respond with the 24 hours. At least give the woman (who has to message the match‚Äù an option to extend that message time so that maybe when the guy logs back on, he has a chance to see the actual message.
title: Needs better features

developerResponse: {'id': 28201486, 'body': "We're sorry to hear you had trouble verifying and getting some support. The selfie you submit is not of you copying your profile photo which is where some of the confusion may lie. We do not tolerate any kind of commercial or promotional behavior on the platform. Any members found to do see whether through a report from you or found by our moderators are actioned upon. Please DM us on Facebook/Twitter (@BumbleSupport) for help!", 'modified': '2022-02-22T20:46:01Z'}
review: This is my second account with Bumble. The first one I had to cancel because I simply tried to verify my account by taking a picture (which seems like the only way to do so) and could not do so. I literally took several photos in the same spots in my house and the app basically told me I‚Äôm not me. The app then locked me out and forced and when I contacted customer service for assistance they suddenly could not find an account for me. So stupidly I started another profile, with some of the same pictures and definitely the same information. So I decided to try and verify my account yet again‚Ä¶.and yet again it will not allow me to verify. I have contacted customer service and have received a basic email with no information that is of use to me. I am now locked out of my account and will likely close my account. This app is really not that user friendly and it makes it impossible to receive any helpful customer service to solve a simple problem. I recognize that verified accounts add another layer of security (which is why I wanted to verify mine) but this is too much trouble! Oh and I‚Äôve yet to find anyone who isn‚Äôt trying to sell something, have me follow them on another site or who isn‚Äôt really married to someone I may know!
title: Customer Service Fail

developerResponse: {'id': 26881152, 'body': "We're so happy to hear you've been able to make meaningful connections in the Hive! We hope you continue to enjoy your time on Bumble! Thanks for being a part of our community. üíõ", 'modified': '2021-12-16T20:28:09Z'}
review: I have been on Bumble since June 2019 and have experienced the tragedies and triumphs and everything in between. As with anything, if your expectation is immediate gratification you will be disappointed. If you are serious, patient, create an attractive profile and above all else, are honest you will make connections. These connections can lead to great conversations and much more. After that, it‚Äôs up to chemistry and no app has that. I have made connection and I waited for the conversation to start and the clock ran out. I have made connection and had second thoughts and let the clock run out. I have also met some amazing people and built lasting relationships. Bumble to me seems safe, exudes quality with the look of the app, the simplicity of use and the opportunity to add additional services for a price. I have done that once but really isn‚Äôt necessary. It is also very easy to update your profile as you learn what seems to be working and maybe what isn‚Äôt. With patience you will connect. Maybe not everyone you swiped right, but likely the right ones. Two tips, be HONEST...about everything including your age, and second, use the extended clock strategically, it can pay dividends. Bumble isn‚Äôt perfect but no dating app is. Happy Bumbling
title: Reasonable Expectations

review:
First of all, how great is it that you can now find a date, friends, and a business partner all in one app?! 
I can‚Äôt speak from a guy‚Äôs perspective, but having had this app for almost 2 years, I can say that it‚Äôs an absolute game changer. I love the concept that ladies get the first move, which as an introvert, I have come to appreciate; It has taught me to be brave and creative when starting conversations with strangers lol. It seems like most people on here are genuine, although I do wish there was just a bit more diversity. I love the time limit concept on the matches, it‚Äôs quite ingenious. It creates a sense of urgency which is great but also has its cons. The app itself is smooth and very user friendly, plus the no limits on swiping is just the icing on the cake. If you don‚Äôt have a paid subscription however, which allows you to see everyone that swiped right on you (amongst other great perks I‚Äôm sure), it can be easy to waste a lot of time on the app just swiping. They also notify users with cute little positive messages and tips every so often and I love it. I haven‚Äôt had any major problems with the app, but I have met some pretty cool people, so don‚Äôt sleep on bumble ya‚Äôll  üíØ
title: Great Concept, Great App!

developerResponse: {'id': 27584620, 'body': "We appreciate you sharing your feedback with us. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience on the app so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team.", 'modified': '2022-01-21T14:45:43Z'}
review: I like the interface and the chat options. That's about it. I use the service because everyone else is here. What I dislike the most is how the chat history disappears when the connection is unmatched. If someone actually wanted to be an adult and end the convo maturely it'll all be for nothing because the other person will never see the last message. Bumble makes everyone ghosters. What if someone wanted to say, "hey I'm getting off here text me at ......" then unmatches everyone cause they don't know what happens on the other end... we'd never know! Second, also in the realm of ghosting, I dislike the 24 hour response window. I'm trying to match with quality men and I don't expect any to log in and respond everyday on a dating app. That means the most valuable matches are risked being lost; forever. These things make the experience very disappointing. Then there are other nuances like auto sending a gif. Or not being able to swipe back to the chat list (instead it initiated the reply function, so annoying). And alerting the other party of you playing the question game... Real smooth Bumble. Please get rid of the timer and deleting the full chat history. If anything change to a fun response if someone responds in the first 24 hours and only removing the chat typing box after an unmatch.
title: High volume, low fun

review: Hi I was really liking this app at first and I was even thinking about purchasing some of the things on the app but then not even two days from starting up my account I get blocked and it‚Äôs saying I was reported for promoting my social medias when I don‚Äôt have any even linked to my account I‚Äôve read through all of the terms and conditions and I‚Äôm very sad that this can just happen for no reason I really want this fixed so that I can use the app and know that I‚Äôm not gonna get kicked off for no reason now I‚Äôm scared make a purchase with you guys because what if I do it and then get blocked when I have not done anything wrong my account is appropriate nothing harmful to others and the fact that I see a bunch of people doing drugs when I was sliding through my swipes and that‚Äôs bad behavior being allowed and I‚Äôm getting blocked for no reason I‚Äôm very mad about it I just really want my account back and an answer to why people are allowed to make false reports ruining other peoples experiences. please get back to me I just really wanna answer to why this can happen and why it‚Äôs happening to me i‚Äôm writing this as a review because it‚Äôs not allowing me to email you guys. even if I was to give my social media to one of my matches it‚Äôs my choice and normal to talk to someone outside of your app once you meet I‚Äôm not just putting it openly on my account.
title: Bad experience so far :(

Email us at bumble.com/contact or message us at Facebook/Twitter (@BumbleSupport).", 'modified': '2022-02-17T21:37:40Z'}
review: I use a few dating apps (Tinder + Hinge as well), and at first I felt like Bumble was the best because I had the option to send a message first, which I liked! Kind of ironic that Bumble actually played out to be the app I feel the most unsafe on. I‚Äôve matched with very sketch people on here. I‚Äôm not sure what it is about this app but most of my matches have all had stalker-like tendencies and when I actually met up with one of them in person (because the others were very obvious red flags concerning SAFETY that I wasn‚Äôt willing to try), I felt completely unsafe because they had continued to stalk me, create new profiles and try to catfish me, followed me under different instagram accounts etc until I finally decided to change my phone number. I did report one instance to Bumble and was not notified on how it was handled. Mind you, went out with this guy ONCE. I‚Äôm still afraid to this day that he is following me somehow. I‚Äôve had A LOT better luck with Hinge specifically, their team is super responsive QUICK and take reports seriously, which makes me feel good! Hinge has been fun and I‚Äôve met great people there! Not sure if it‚Äôs because Bumble requires the woman to make the first move‚Ä¶? I think the waiting game culminates into an obsessive kind of behavior, personally. Would not recommend to friends (I tell them stick with Hinge).
title: Feels unsafe

developerResponse: {'id': 23551017, 'body': "Hi there, we really appreciate you sharing your detailed feedback with us. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience on the app so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team.", 'modified': '2021-06-23T19:21:21Z'}
review:
In my past experiences with this app, I‚Äôve met a handful of people, and most of my dates. The key thing to getting a decent amount of matches is great pics and a great bio (traditionally known). Although, it may still be hard to get even one match because people commonly have busy lives, hence don‚Äôt check their Bumble. Others just won‚Äôt care and will ghost you. But, who am I to judge? I personally prefer to meet people in person, as it‚Äôs the old fashioned way. I believe Bumble is one of the best, if not the best app to meet new people. I‚Äôve personally had numerous accounts with Bumble after deleting and reinstalling it SO many times.
One thing that discourages me is that there can be so many attractive people in your area but not only is it possible to not have likes, but just to get noticed I feel like you have to buy spotlight. I definitely feel like it‚Äôs way easier for women to get matches compared to men, but I may also be wrong. Unless you are an EXPERT with patience, and you only have an interaction here and there, I think it‚Äôs best to meet people in person. I know we live in a digital world, but still don‚Äôt believe dating apps are for everyone. My advice, try the app. If it bears good fruit, God bless. If it doesn‚Äôt, stay away.
title: Can be good, but it‚Äôs not for everyone.

review:
I was swiping on Bumble when a notification to be in the spotlight popped up on my phone. Not realizing it, I accidentally clicked on the package and tried to exit out. It was then that the payment screen came up and when I was trying to click the button to exit, it quickly accepted my fingerprint for payment.

I quickly notified Bumble and got a generic response from ‚ÄúMike‚Äù from the ‚ÄúBumble Feedback Team‚Äù saying sorry it‚Äôs in the terms that we can‚Äôt refund your purchase. I emailed him back that I‚Äôm trying to pay for school and was recently laid off and I could really use the money. He quickly got back to me with the SAME EXACT generic email saying sorry it‚Äôs in the terms. It‚Äôs obvious that he doesn‚Äôt care and so I emailed him. I understand, but accidents happen. Please make the exception. He hasn‚Äôt emailed me back.

Bumble is this how you train your employees? You pay them to send generic, careless emails to your users? You write in your email to please provide us with feedback as we‚Äôre always looking to improve. How about you go the extra mile with your customer service and show that you actually care about the service you are providing to the users and not just money grabbing. Keep employees like ‚ÄúMike‚Äù from the ‚ÄúBumble Feedback Team‚Äù! It‚Äôs clear he doesn‚Äôt have pride in the company he works for and the job that he does for you. Judging by the way you handle your customers, I can understand why.
title: Bad Customer Service

developerResponse: {'id': 16297032, 'body': "Thanks for sharing your candid experience. We understand these changes have had an impact and we're here to ease the transition. We incorporated a swipe limit to encourage thoughtful swiping, but it sounds like you may be having technical difficulty with your limit. DM us on Facebook or Twitter @BumbleSupport‚Äîwe'd love to help!", 'modified': '2020-06-29T23:43:38Z'}
review:
I‚Äôve used bumble for about 2 years now and have even managed to meet one of my ex girlfriends on there. Additionally, I think the fundamental aspect of having the woman strike up conversation first is a HUGE bonus, when you consider how unlikely it is for them to do so on other apps. 

HOWEVER, the company is going in a greedy direction, starting with two significant features: the amount of swipes and the reverse button (if you accidentally swiped left). In the last 6 months or so Bumble has significantly reduced your amount of swipes, which is of course a far more important issue for your average man than woman. Most of these other apps that I‚Äôve used employ this feature of limited swipes, but Bumble used to give you so many more swipes (it might‚Äôve been unlimited) nowadays I‚Äòll
 swipe on like 25 people before running out and having to wait a day? My matches have significantly dropped and it‚Äôs almost pointless to have this app because it‚Äôs just like all the other ones now. The aforementioned features are what made it different (and better!), but it seems like they want you to pay for them now, which is understandable (paying more for more services) but how does it differentiate from the myriad of other apps that have saturated the market? I don‚Äôt know. Personally, it‚Äôs not enough of an incentive to keep this spacious app on my phone.
title: Fixing what‚Äôs not broken

review:
I redownloaded the app a while ago and after every few swipes there was an ad for a ‚Äúfree trial‚Äù for bumble boost. It was annoying to constantly have it pop up so I figured I‚Äôd give it a try. Come to find out that I was automatically charged for a 3 month subscription. It should have clearly been stated that I was not eligible for the free trial (bc apparently I had tried it years ago even though I don‚Äôt remember) but instead they just automatically charge you. This is false advertising!!! I realized this one hour into it and tried to email bumble and cancel and this is what bumble responded with ‚ÄúThe reason this instant charge happened was because Apple deemed you not eligible for a trial, possibly because you have already had one previously for Bumble under a different account. In this case it is Apple that chooses to charge you immediately and that's unfortunately out of our control.‚Äù
I asked if they couldn‚Äôt cancel it entirely to at least switch me to a one month subscription but they said no. How did they decide to sign me up for the 3 month versus at least a 1 month trial?? This is very misleading and deceptive. So shady and money hungry.
title: False advertising

review:
This event happened over a year ago and I‚Äôve yet to receive any response or for of communication from anyone from the Bumble team. 

I matched with this girl and from the beginning I should‚Äôve seen the red flags. We met up to hang out then insisted I go back to her place. I was hesitant to do it but I wasn‚Äôt expecting anything bad to happen. After a few drinks we were sitting on the couch and she started touching me. I wasn‚Äôt comfortable with the way this was happening so I told her to stop. Needless to say she didn‚Äôt. She just kept touching me. I must‚Äôve offended her because she insulted me and said I must not like girls if I didn‚Äôt consent, then proceeded to grab me. I‚Äôm a large man so I was able to get her away and left. I went to report her in the app but it seems she had gotten to me first. I couldn‚Äôt even go to the police if I wanted to because I had no way of getting her name or info because bumble banned my profile and any new ones I try to create. I‚Äôve sent countless emails to them hoping to get unbanned or at least the information from the girl. I even attached as much evidence as I could to support my claims, but haven‚Äôt hear a single word. All I want is to make sure this doesn‚Äôt happen to other men or people in general. Seems like the team at bumble isn‚Äôt very worried about the safety of their users. At this point I don‚Äôt want to make another profile I just want help.
title: Help

developerResponse: {'id': 5912222, 'body': 'Hi there! We appreciate your feedback. Hundreds of users make successful connections on the app every day, and we are certain that you can as well. Feel free to message us on Facebook (@bumbleapp) or Twitter (@bumble) if we can offer any tips or support. We are here for you!', 'modified': '2018-11-12T18:55:53Z'}
review: I find it very odd that every guy I‚Äôve matched has either never talked or we start talking and I suddenly never hear back from them again. I‚Äôve only exchanged numbers with two guys on this app and one suddenly disappears after we talked all night and he agreed to take me surfing and the other guy stops talking. All the guys I‚Äôve matched with stop talking mid conversation this has happened 100 percent of the time. I‚Äôve had at least 12+ matches and have been using this app for about a week, I‚Äôd say I‚Äôm a very attractive woman and have never had problems getting a date so I find it odd that this has happened every single time. The Bumble Bff does this as well but not as badly so I‚Äôve stopped using the dating side of Bumble as it‚Äôs super suspect and I haven‚Äôt had any success with any of the guys I‚Äôve matched with. I also think their are quite a few fake profiles as well but seeing all the bad reviews I‚Äôm starting to believe this app is just trying to get you to spend money as it takes so many swipes just to see whose liked you. Mine said I had 50+ likes and it stayed that way because Bumble won‚Äôt reveal even one of them for a very long time unless you pay for an upgrade. I find it odd that I can‚Äôt match with any rally handsome guys on the app but when I go out I attract good looking guys all the time. Anyways I just wanted everyone to know my experience. It‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs this app.
title: The worst dating app I‚Äôve ever used.

developerResponse: {'id': 34805283, 'body': "Hi there. We're sorry you didn't enjoy your experience on Bumble. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team. While we continue to work hard to improve this, if we can help your experience further right now, please send us a message at bumble.com/contact. üíõ", 'modified': '2023-02-11T04:51:21Z'}
review:
Who likes dating apps? Not me, because it feels like I‚Äôm shopping for a person and putting myself on a market (which is really what dating apps are for, obviously). 

However, with the free version, you can send messages to matches (they have 24 hours to respond) and you have unlimited messages once you match. In addition, Bumble adapts. I actually like that they changed it to only allowing you to view/like a few people at a time ‚Äî it helps keep you logging in, so you maybe won‚Äôt miss messages with/from matches. A downside to this change, though, is that I always have, like, 50 likes (most of them I won‚Äôt like back because we‚Äôre clearly incompatible in some way), and it‚Äôs going to take longer to make matches with those likes. But, anything good takes time‚Ä¶ so, I guess that makes sense. 

Bumble is doing alright ‚Äî with BFF (helpful when you‚Äôve moved to a new state!) and with Date. If I‚Äôm going to pay for a dating app, I wouldn‚Äôt mind paying them to upgrade (versus others so far tried that like to limit everything you do until you pay for it, and limit to extreme lengths). If a free version says a lot about an app (which is generally true), the free version of this one is effective and user-friendly.
title: User-friendly and safe

developerResponse: {'id': 16733169, 'body': "Thanks for sharing your candid feedback. We work to keep the Hive a safe and authentic place to encourage thoughtful engagement that leads to meaningful connection. Your profile is shown before or after a Spotlight‚Äîit helps move your profile to the top of Swipe Decks for a short time. DM us on Facebook/Twitter @BumbleSupport if you'd like to chat!", 'modified': '2020-07-20T01:42:51Z'}
review:
I'd say half the profiles are zombie accoumts of women who have zero intention of dating you and just want to add followers to their Instagram accounts or promote their businesses. I know this because I came across three profiles of friends who I know for a fact are not available. 
And how do you know your profile is being shown to people? You have no way of knowing. There is zero transparency. So there you are, right-swiping hundreds of lovelies with hopes high and fingers crossed, and you'll never know if tney even saw you. 
What the app is exceptionally good at is extracting money from you in a series of scammy, unverifiable gimmicks that prey on your vulnerabilities. "Boost" your profile for $2-4 to be seen by more people for 30 whole minutes! What, are you saying you weren't showing my profile before?! "Super-swipe" at $1-3 a pop so she may or may not take notice of you! Their exploitation of human weaknesses at our moments of greatest vulnerability - e.g loneliness and rejection - is masterful and deeply sinister. 
Finally, gentlemen (and ladies), remember that all these dating apps only make money while you're still on them. So their incentive to make more money is fundamentally misaligned with yours, which is to find a decent match so you can leave the app. Go meet real people through real friends, and save yourself a crapton of money, headache and heartache. Bumble is not your friend.
title: A thoroughly miserable, exploitative experience for men

developerResponse: {'id': 11603183, 'body': "Thank you for sharing your feedback!
