review: My old iPhone broke so I had to get a new one. When I opened Bumble on my new phone, I accidentally pressed create a new account. There is no way to move backwards or press settings from this screen. It just wants me to add photos or add my birth date as though I am creating a new account. I can‚Äôt log out and then log in with my real account. The Bumble help team has not been helpful and there isn‚Äôt even a contact number. I have been communicating through email, and each time there is a different person who does not seem to care about the issue or gives suggestions that I can‚Äôt follow because I‚Äôm stuck on the create a new account screen. I believe if developers were to vet peoples BIOs, and not allow any promotion of social media/websites etc., I think we could weed out the clout chasers and actually have ourselves a pretty decent dating app. I would say that about 30% of girls on the app are there there to promote their instagram accounts. developerResponse: {'id': 26943724, 'body': 'Thanks for updating your review.\nWe always appreciate feedback from our users.', 'modified': '2022-02-03T03:45:05Z'}
review: This was a pretty good app for the purpose.  Fairly user friendly, especially until a few updates ago (when they made it much harder to tell which setting you were on or to switch settings).  Does a decent job of verifying profiles and trying to protect users.  HOWEVER, they force updates on you, and the latest update (Aug. ‚Äò21) won‚Äôt work unless you have a newer iPad capable of running OS 13 or higher.  I have lost access to my profiles, my conversations, and my matches.  Yes, there is a desktop version, but the program isn‚Äôt smart enough to figure out that a user might log in on more than one device.  Instead, it forces you to make a new profile even with the same phone number, name, and birthdate.  It‚Äôs hard to trust a dating app that runs multiple profiles for the same person.  I no longer recommend.

1. You are being told this and not given any factual reason or evidence. 
2. Trying to contact them after being blocked is almost impossible, created a new account and I email support. I received a email from a Grace saying that your account is permanently blocked and this decision can not be changed. Again with no reason and no evidence. 
3. I am a massage therapist and work usually comes up in a conversation. I have never tried to sell my services or ask for money.

When I messaged him that it would be more positive if he put his interests and hobbies instead he then sent me snapshots of messages he sent to his friends making fun of me. Just the violation of my profile being discussed with people other than the person I matched with has completely turned me off Bumble. I reported him and I hope he is banned. Bumble does nothing to mitigate this type of behavior because men get a huge ego boost from women messaging them on this app. Bumble continues to market this as ‚Äúwe empower women‚Äù. However, clearly from this experience, it is the complete opposite. It‚Äôs sad that Bumble mindlessly pushes the same message over and over again at the expense of women just so they can make money.

review:
Since everyone is stuck inside, bumble knows that human interaction is desired, so what do they do? They remove the ability to back swipe, and give you limited swipes per day (like 5-10 way less than Tinder). You don‚Äôt even know what you‚Äôre in for when you start. At least Hinge tells you that you get 10 likes a day.

The premium is so much money compared to other services.

Also, I can‚Äôt help but feel like everyone‚Äôs accusations that they focus on people just coming back to the app/starting over regular users and prioritize them so you can get them addicted. The signs are there.

They removed everything that made humble okay to deal with and put it under premium. They can‚Äôt get their location correct, you get way more matches when entering somewhere new, rather than staying in your city, and don‚Äôt tell you where the limits are at.

On top of that, they‚Äôre telling people ‚Äúwe made limits in order to focus on quality matches.‚Äù If that were true, why can you have unlimited matches under premium? Are they less quality for $50 bucks a month?

Yeah go to Hinge. It‚Äôs not 100% superficial like Tinder, and you can impress a person by you charisma. Bumble creates an atmosphere where most people never have a chance at finding love.

review:
While I like the ease of flipping through, there are some issues with how the app works, or the overall rules of the app. The part about people just disappearing. I really liked to use this app at one time, but it‚Äôs taken a big step downward ‚Äî and now I‚Äôm normally using Tinder again or other apps. The two problems I have with it: The back button (a great feature) is basically unusable unless you want to pay, and the new swipe limit is absolutely stupid. These are both money grabs. I‚Äôve heard these changes characterized as a way to get users to swipe thoughtfully, but clearly they are squeezing money out of people. Just own it, Bumble.

What‚Äôs even more aggravating is this comes at a time when people are on LOCK DOWN. I just moved, and I thought, ‚ÄúWell, this is one way to meet some people without having to go to crowded places.‚Äù I know next to no one here, and these changes to help me ‚Äúswipe more thoughtfully‚Äù weren‚Äôt very well thought out and aren‚Äôt helpful.

Bumble: I‚Äôm swiping left on you.
title: No longer a great app

review: I love the fact that girls message first, since it prevents you from getting unwanted messages from creepy guys. However, all of the premium features like boost or super swipe cost WAYYY too much money, and if you don‚Äôt get boost, you rarely actually come across the people in your beeline. Also, ‚Äúsomething casual‚Äù is a little vague - there should be a ‚Äúhookup‚Äù option instead since many of the people who put ‚Äúsomething casual‚Äù mean ‚Äúhookup‚Äù but not all of them. Because of this lack of specificity, I‚Äôve come across many guys who are looking for a hookup but don‚Äôt reveal it until we‚Äôre talking. While this app seems to have more of a chance to find people looking for relationships than others, it still makes it hard to do so in many ways.

developerResponse: {'id': 31643329, 'body': "Thanks for reaching out to us! Bumble is always looking for new ways to improve the experience of our members. We really appreciate you taking the time to leave us your feedback about this, and we'll be sure to share it with our Product Team.", 'modified': '2022-08-24T17:21:16Z'}
review:
I‚Äôve been using Bumble on & off for a few years - here‚Äôs what you should know:

* From what I can tell, about 80% of the profiles are ‚Äúinactive.‚Äù That is, someone set it up, used it for while, deleted the app but not their profile. Bumble does NOT delete profiles, even after whenever created it disappeared years ago. 

* I would say if the remaining 15% of profiles, the person checks it maybe once a month or so, which means that whomever has swiped on them has also gone missing.

* Since women make the first move (I wonder how that works in people seeking same-sex relationships), even after ‚Äúmatching,‚Äù the match ‚Äúexpires‚Äù about 90% of the time. The remaining 10% will carry on a few single word answers (‚ÄúHi!‚Äù) and then disappear.

The problem with Bumble, like all the other dating apps, is there there is no transparency or accountability. There is no way of knowing whether a profile is ‚Äúactive,‚Äù if the person logs in regularly, or whether they are interested in anything more than ‚Äúlooking to see who‚Äôs out there.‚Äù

If you don‚Äôt pay for any of the services and check it daily, you have about a 1% chance of success.
title: It‚Äôs online dating, so you know it‚Äôs going to be a train wreck

developerResponse: {'id': 25199523, 'body': "Hi there, thank you so much for giving us this feedback, and we'll be sure to pass it on to our Product Team so we can continue to improve the app. In the meantime our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@bumblesupport) so we can get you back up and buzzin'.", 'modified': '2021-09-20T07:28:24Z'}
review:
It‚Äôs been about 3 months since I dated last (pandemic life). I decided to jump on Bumble because I remember the caliber of women are higher on this platform. But I went into this experiment unemotional. Post good quality photos, some in groups, others in activities, with a couple of professional shots from a family shoot last year.

I filled out all of the prompts giving thoughtful , interesting responses, and connected my IG. Then I paid for premium to get all the perks. 

In a month, I‚Äôve gotten 4 matches. Only 1 actually started a conversation and left it hanging. The ‚Äúlikes‚Äù I received were bottom of the barrel.

I spent at least an hour daily swiping, reacting, and sending super likes. I am tall, average body type, dress well, average to better than average looks, good job, no fishing pics, no shirtless selfies. 

Bumble like every other app presents itself as the dating app that empowers women. Unfortunately, women don‚Äôt like making the first move proven by the dozens if not hundreds of bios that say so explicitly. Add to that that the men on the app swipe right willy nilly and you get women who are overwhelmed and don‚Äôt want to start thoughtful conversations (gathered from the half dozen or so close female friends I‚Äôve talked to about dating apps)
title: Bumble isn‚Äôt interested in getting you a Date

review: I‚Äôve had luck on other apps and even on this one but years ago. Now it‚Äôs pretty stale and I‚Äôll log on periodically once every few months to see the same people. Buy a subscription, match with a handful of women, only a couple actually message with something very generic and might get a date out of it. I swipe through my area in less than a week and I seem to get shadow banned from swiping, where people can‚Äôt see me - even people I‚Äôve matched with before. Really doesn‚Äôt seem worth the time or money, Bumble still asks you to pay for other features after you‚Äôve already got Boost so I don‚Äôt see the point. Overall very disappointing when I used to get tons of matches on here with people eager to meet. I think the format of women messaging first is bad and the constant political pushing is exhausting. Everything feels forced and restricted which is no fun. Might as well go elsewhere.

One more thing:  why put the location (where they are and where they live) all the way at the bottom?  That‚Äôs THE most important factor for me.  If someone is just visiting my city, there is no way I want to match them.  Yet I have to read through and consider their entire profile before I reach this crucial info.

review:
This site fought my attention as I feel that with the climate of today, having women take charge of what they want is a great idea and should be mandatory. Unfortunately, I am not sure this is the platform for that. 

There seems to be many either fake profile bots that target accounts that are close to closing just to keep generating interest. There is a validate button but the bots will never verify as well as humans. It might be a good idea to implement the validation prior to joining. This should eliminate the bots unless the programmers and marketers want to keep people‚Äôs interests. Also, Men should be free on this app as they really can not do anything within the app except swipe right. 

Yes, speaking about swipe right, there needs to be a method of retracting that back as a right handed person will swipe some if not most on accident if holding the devise with one hand. Just sending the accidental card swipe then having to make things more awkward is probably not good in your analytics data. 

And one last big thing, please fix how your algorithm 
Matches people up. At some point, the choices and filters become null making the experience quite difficult. 

Other than that, the application could be the best out there. Proper matching query, actual responses from real human people and you got a winner.
title: Could be better

It‚Äôs starting to feel too much like Tinder. VERY superficial guys so far. I‚Äôm disappointed.
title: Not quite what I was hoping for

review: So I did a small experiment as I do with all dating apps. I only swiped right. I had major success on Tinder, and switched over to bumble to see how the app fared. I swiped right on a lot of accounts and only got a single match in about 3 days. I then proceeded to pay for the premium perks to seeing I was missing something and surprise the transaction went through and it didn‚Äôt even give me the benefits. Luckily there‚Äôs a 2 week free trial but rip my 8 dollars anyways. Seems like there‚Äôs a lot of inactive accounts, or just straight up fake accounts bumble doesn‚Äôt care about. You‚Äôd have to swipe for weeks as a guy. I‚Äôm not saying I‚Äôm some attractive Greek god, but I had an interesting bio and somewhat good looking. Honestly I heard it was incredibly hard for his to find matches but didn‚Äôt believe it. Through testing i can confirm it‚Äôs not worth the time or the outrageous paid options on the list. Thank you next
title: Not exactly functional

review:
So the geniuses at Bumble don‚Äôt give you the OPTION to define where you live or choose the neighborhood where you want to date.  So if you live in Malibu but were displaced by the fires - your bumble profile may list your location as Tarzana - or wherever you happen to spend that night.  How dumb is that?! You can‚Äôt even use your driver‚Äôs license to establish your location! No option free or as a premium feature to allow you to choose ‚ÄòRoam‚Äô - when you go traveling. The result? If you live in New York City and are going to a convention in Nebraska - good luck lining up a date when you return to Manhattan - but you‚Äôll have a SLEW of Omaha housewives interested in a long term relationship, marriage and children! ü§£ 

Why not give us the option??

Bumble seems like such a good concept - but this is the fatal flaw that keeps eligible singles from finding their partners and ruins the dating experience.  üëé

review: The interface for this app was just changed, and the update is extremely cumbersome to use. I used to be able to review full sized pictures all at once and then read through the bio if there was an attraction to determine a final left or right swipe. Now cropped pictures are jumbled together with pieces of the bio, and if you want to see the full size pictures you have to click on each one individually then click back, scroll and hope the next picture stops in the frame of your phone, and repeat. The double tap to zoom feature is gone too. I can understand the desire for the app to want to present a fuller understanding of each person, but with the absence of any other filtering, there are a lot of people to review and the new interface makes that awkward and frustrating. I hope they change it back because I‚Äôm not as interested in using the app now.
title: Cumbersome interface

review: I was skeptical to try Bumble because I‚Äôve been disappointed with other dating apps. I am incredibly impressed with the quality of matches so far, in that there are many attractive, eligible, career-driven guys and sadly I cannot say the same for most other apps. I love the simple format of a few pictures and a brief profile instead of an exhaustive list of attributes and qualities. Having to mutually swipe right before a conversation can start is also a breath of fresh air, versus Match, where you get inundated with messages from guys you‚Äôre not interested in. I‚Äôve used the app for less than a week and already had one successful date. Keep up the awesome work, Bumble!
title: Impressed so far

review: For an app marketed as a dating app it‚Äôs weird that you can delete the dating portion and keep BFF or Bizz but can‚Äôt do the opposite. It‚Äôs been years since this app has been on the market so they should probably figure out how to make that happen. Bumble has gone downhill in recent years. Everyone is out to make a quick buck. Without paying you used to be able to set 2 filters for profiles. Heaven forbid I want to make sure people I swipe on are verified accounts and make sure the individuals I want to date don‚Äôt smoke. Now you have to pay for any additional filter. It‚Äôs a cash grab. And don‚Äôt get me started on making this a safe space by having women make the first move. What a joke.
title: I thought this was supposed to be a dating app

review: Overall the app itself is decent enough and straightforward to use. However, I find myself compelled to write a review hoping that SOMEBODY will finally fix this problem I‚Äôve had through many updates. I pay for premium so that I can see my ‚Äúbeeline‚Äù of people who have already matched with me. Whenever I am scrolling through it will periodically just glitch me back to the top of my list for no reason. It is infuriating. As well the message notifications do not always come through immediately which makes it a little frustrating to keep up with a faster paced conversation and I always ultimately ask my matches if they‚Äôd like to chat on another platform. Hopefully this means SOMETHING to the bumble developers
title: Needs work PLEASE

review:
Bumble is consistently the worst of the major dating apps on the market. 

User base:
In all the years I‚Äôve had Bumble, I‚Äôve gotten I think two matches, and one of them never even responded. For example: right now I supposedly have 26 likes (I don‚Äôt pay for the app), but despite all the right swiping I do, I haven‚Äôt had a match in so long I‚Äôve lost track of time. Even when I had a paid subscription, only one of all my matches actually messaged me. I understand the gimmick is to let the girl message first, but in my experience most girls don‚Äôt message first so the whole point of the app is a drawback 

User interface:
Standard tinder ripoff, but the swipe function is so ludicrously sensitive that I often accidentally swipe just because of the way I‚Äôm holding the phone. 

User experience:
I get daily notifications from Bumble, usually multiple a day, and it gets very annoying. I like that prompts are an option but a significant number of profiles don‚Äôt answer any of them and are usually only a couple words.

Summary:
Inactive/unresponsive users, annoying amount of notifications, almost no matches despite almost daily notifications that I have a new like, all in all just a frustrating disappointment
title: Worst of the popular dating apps

title: Major swiping flaws

review:
This is an app for singles who just can‚Äôt get enough spam about astrology, but also want to dabble in dating.

You‚Äôd think that if you chose not to list your star sign on your profile then maybe you‚Äôre not someone who‚Äôd want to be relentlessly flooded with astrology spam. Not so. Astrology marketing *is* the goal for this app ‚Äî you can‚Äôt even opt out of it if you want to. Delete one of Bumble‚Äôs own astrology spambots and you‚Äôll just get another one. Try to block it, and they just keep coming.

For the dating app that it pretends to be‚Ä¶ it has its flaws. Accidental right-swipes and superswipes are much too easy to perform by accident. It wouldn‚Äôt be hard for the devs to put a quick-undo delay in there, and they‚Äôve known about this for years, but it‚Äôs just not their focus. The focus is astrology marketing.

review:
Great app. Opened me up to lots of new connections. Be respectfulI've used this App and even enrolled in Bumble Boost. Some reviews complain that once you sign up for premium services at a cost the there is 'no way out'. This is not true. To cancel a subscription (at least on an iPhone), access your Apple ID through Settings, tap your ID at the top of the screen, select subscriptions, and cancel.

Otherwise, my experience on this App has been exceptional. It's a good way to meet people you would otherwise not encounter.

My advice, be honest with your profile and intentions...and respect people with whom you chat, they're humans as well.
title: Like it a lot!

review: While Bumble allows users to pick from a long list of gender options, your choice doesn‚Äôt impact how you are shown in the algorithm. Immediately after selecting your gender, you are required to choose between being shown to people ‚Äúlooking for women‚Äù or people ‚Äúlooking for men,‚Äù which undermines the function of choosing your gender to begin with. This makes it challenging for people who don‚Äôt easily pass as one of the binaries to use the app. It seems like the issue could be easily solved with a third option - choosing to be shown to people ‚Äúlooking for everyone.‚Äù Everyone who uses the app has to specify if they are interested in ‚Äúmen,‚Äù ‚Äúwomen,‚Äù or ‚Äúeveryone,‚Äù so it seems like there should be a pretty straightforward matching data set. I‚Äôve emailed support about it several times, though, and have been told they will think about it, without any change happening.
title: Not a trans-friendly app

review:
This app is that borderline between girls looking for a relationship and girls looking for fun. Half the girls are looking for dating, half - for fun. Let me tell you what‚Äôs on the market: Hinge is trying too hard to be about relationships, Tinder is getting more fake by the day, and Bumble.. nails it. There are a lot of pretty girls on here, not sure about guys. The fact that a girl has to write first is a mild help, since they rarely wrote anything meaningful, but a help nonetheless.
In addition, I think I‚Äôve had one of the most interesting conversations on a dating app here: we‚Äôve talked about our career ambitions, how would technology change that and so on. 
Definitely the best dating/hookup app right now.

review: Starting off I just want to point out that I‚Äôm all for equality and empowerment for any person but this whole ‚Äúwomen have to initiate conversation‚Äù thing is just a terrible feature. 90% of my matches expire after the 24 hour time limit and it‚Äôs incredibly frustrating having to wait around and see if they‚Äôll actually message or not. I think adding a feature where any person can message after 12 hours would greatly improve this app. Besides this point I think a few more prompt questions could be added. I do think that all of the info you can put about yourself is a great feature that tinder doesn‚Äôt have. Overall as a male I‚Äôd stick with tinder over bumble just because I can actually message my matches at least one time and it doesn‚Äôt feel like a total waste of time and effort.

To get your hopes up after a match was made, meaning you both say you are potentially interested, only to have to watch as the time limit for the woman to reach out expires, and you have no way of starting a conversation in any form was like this app was just a sick game.  They even give you the ability to give the woman more time to respond, which just adds insult to injury.  We are so disconnected with each other, and gamified dating apps, which is what this ultimately felt like, makes that reality even more depressing.
title: Ridiculous and Depressing App

Send us a message on Facebook or Twitter @BumbleSupport so our team can clear up any confusion and improve your experience!", 'modified': '2020-09-10T20:14:17Z'}
review:
Bumble says that it wants to reverse traditional gender roles in dating by creating a platform where the woman makes the first move, and that it will always be free. However, in practice, if a woman ‚Äúlikes‚Äù a man‚Äôs profile first, he cannot see hers unless he pays for an additional service (or randomly ‚Äúlikes‚Äù hers on his own). Which means, if he doesn‚Äôt pay, her first move isn‚Äôt rewarded and the system defeats its own stated objective.

The only way for a man to proceed for free is to ‚Äúlike‚Äù a woman‚Äôs profile, and when she ‚Äúlikes‚Äù his back, then she can make ‚Äúthe first move,‚Äù but he has clearly already made the first move by ‚Äúliking‚Äù her profile first.

It‚Äôs not perfect, but maybe it‚Äôs taking a step in the right direction. Such is our pursuit of love, no?

Just like every other dating app, there‚Äôs a daily limit to how much you swipe. However on bumble I think for the past couple of months I‚Äôve only been able to swipe for 10 people.
I got over 50 different people in my ‚Äúbeeline‚Äù that I‚Äôm waiting to match with but I can only swipe about 10 times in a 24 hour time period.

I hope this helps!', 'modified': '2021-08-31T16:40:09Z'}
review: For reference I‚Äôm 32, male, LA-based. I‚Äôve been on the app for 3-4 months now, and while I enjoy certain aspects of it (profile format and ease of use), it really is a giant cash grab. It tells me every few days I have a ‚Äúnew like‚Äù, exciting right? Instead of ever showing me who is sending the likes, they hold them hostage until you pay for their premium beeline subscription to see everything. The only time this was different was when I was out of town in a smaller city, and I guess I was a more ‚Äúsought after‚Äù person, so they‚Äôd actually show me who liked me every day or two. Right now I have 24 likes and counting, just waiting in my queue, with no expectation that I‚Äôll ever see them until I pay. Coffee meets bagel and hinge have been better experiences, though they are all greedy imo.

review:
I purchased a Bumble Premium subscription. It didn‚Äôt activate in the app. I contacted support, and the auto-responder promised a response within 48 hours. 48 hours passed, so I sent another support request, which also went 48 hours with no response. I finally tried to get a refund through the App Store, but apparently Bumble is special and you can‚Äôt get a refund. 

If this review shows up on the App Store page, maybe it will get one of those developer responses where a social media manager says this is not the experience Bumble wants its customers to have and invites me to send an email to the address I have already sent more than one message to. 

More likely, though, this review will end up at the bottom of the list, you‚Äôll never see it, and I‚Äôll never get a refund for the money I wasted on this predatory app.
title: Bumble customer support does not exist

developerResponse: {'id': 23246411, 'body': "Hi there, we appreciate you sharing your feedback with us. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience on the app so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team.", 'modified': '2021-06-07T16:54:50Z'}
review: This app advertises that it‚Äôs free to use, but if you actually want to use the app with any hopes of meeting someone, you need to pay. It‚Äôs like all the other dating sites in that way. They make it seem like it‚Äôs free, because it‚Äôs free to create a profile and swipe forever. They use some very clever marketing to create the illusion of choice. I would have more respect for the developers if they just put the paywall at the beginning. As an independent woman, I would rather pay for the experience, evaluate if it‚Äôs worth the money, than be manipulated. I would rather look at ads than be told something is free to use when it‚Äôs not. Considering everything we have all gone through with the pandemic, the developers need to show some integrity and either make the app actually free with ads or charge a membership.
title: Just put the paywall at the beginning

review: Like other reviews I‚Äôve read, I walked into using this app to go on dates and eventually try my luck and love and marriage. I have gotten matched before but I have literally never messaged with someone back and forth on this app. I know I‚Äôm not the most handsome guy but definitely not the ugliest or the rudest or anything. Just becomes more deflating to continuously use this app and never have anyone match with me. I can‚Äôt even tell if the profile is real or not. They have the face verification thing, but even then you could use that, delete your profile, and have it still show up in results, so you really can‚Äôt trust IF the person is real and is actively using the app. Disappointing waste of time. I‚Äôll be looking to use other apps moving forward.

review: In an effort to get you to pay to see who has liked you, bumble likes to stack up a bunch if profiles in your ‚ÄúBee Line‚Äù that of course are blurred out until you pay to see them. I‚Äôve been on Bumble for a couple of years and this is a scam. Because there is nobody in my Bee Line for days ‚Äî until I no longer pay. Then, miraculously, a bunch of people start stacking up as soon as I‚Äôm not paying any more. Of course, if I pay to see the profiles, they are a bunch of people who don‚Äôt fit my filter at all. They are 100 miles away, way too young, way too old, or my favorite: just flat out fake profiles created by Bumble to keep you engaged. Nicely played, Bumble. Personally, I can‚Äôt wait to be a part of the lawsuit when other people figure this out. You sure tell a great story about being here to help people when the reality is you‚Äôre just exploiting them.

I‚Äôm glad there is an option to show if they‚Äôre looking for a relationship or something casual but I wish I can filter the casual out (some are lazy to even fill that in). review:
I like bumble overall but the snooze mode feature either needs to be changed or more transparent with how it works. 
If I go off snooze mode, it notifies all my matches that I‚Äôm back and encourages them to interact with me- it makes the assumption that when I turn it off I WANT all of them to talk to me which isn‚Äôt always the case. 
It also notified someone who I went on a date with right after (72 hours of snooze had passed) causing confusion. He thought I wasn‚Äôt interested anymore. 
This is an awful feature - if I want to be invisible, nobody has to know if I don‚Äôt want them to. 
Only tinder has this type of feature set up correctly - though I don‚Äôt use it for other reasons.
title: One Complaint: snooze mode

review: For the most part I like the app. However, there are few adjustments that. Oils make the app better. Why is there a time limit once you match with someone to begin communication? review: I signed up for bumble and within a few months they changed my name ID to the word moderated. It meant that I was being moderated and anyone is on my profile saw that. this is what happens if you‚Äôre inappropriate. iMessage them and ask them why. They said to send them my phone number and email. Because I have but that‚Äôs on the App Store, they didn‚Äôt have my email. It took about eight emails back-and-forth to get directions on how to send them the encoded email. Then they explain that my name needed to be my real name. I said I wanted privacy. they said you have to use your real name so that it‚Äôs authentic. No respect that people don‚Äôt want their real name. Plus the support was really inconsistent and getting different messages back and no clear instructions on how to address this basic problem. It took about six weeks.

  BUT we need a neutral button, or a skip. Some profiles don‚Äôt seem to have anything written in them. They just have three or four pictures. I always hate to just swipe left and  say no but at the same time I don‚Äôt have any information to go on to know if we have any shared likes or interests, so we really need a neutral button or a skip button so if they read everything  we wrote and are interested, they could click on us, and have a match without us having to click on an empty profile as a match.

review: Im here to share my short and concise review about my experience on bumble. I‚Äôve been using this app for probably a couple of years at this point and I can confidently say that it‚Äôs the worst out of all the apps. For context I use the dating section. I barley get any matches and the ones I do the women never reply. The fact that matches expire after a day is really lame. You don‚Äôt get enough free swipes on this app, seems like I swipe 10 times and I‚Äôm out for the next 24 hours. Omg the premium prices are ridiculous and doesn‚Äôt effect getting more matches at all. Only positive thing I can say is the UI and concept is good. I thought tinder was bad but this is worse. review: I was messaging a veteran who was my age 36. He asked if I liked to go to the shooting range I said yes. He told me what guns he has. I don‚Äôt have any guns. I don‚Äôt have any guns. So they left. They also went to the man‚Äôs house I was talking to. They had to check if his guns were registered to him. They‚Äôre registered to nobody because we live in Arizona and guns aren‚Äôt registered here. Period. So this app reads all your messages and if you talk about any of our American amendments they‚Äôll call the FBI on you. Bumble is highly against the first amendment. Bumble doesn‚Äôt belobe in privacy nor free speech whatsoever. I am proof. Horrible, anti American app. Trash.

With so many prospective matches, there‚Äôs no reason to care about any specific one of them at all. There‚Äôs always another one a swipe away. On top of that, the number of scammers and bots is appalling as well and it seems like some of them can evade detection through verification. So you can‚Äôt invest in anyone on the app, and it seems like no one else does either. One wrong move, one misstep, and anyone you‚Äôve been talking to for days is now gone. After that I actually started getting interesting matches to pop up. App is super glitchy. review: This app is great, way more comprehensive than Tinder and clearly the leading app in this space. The only complaint I have it not being able to add/remove profile prompts at will. I get they may be part of creating a comprehensive profile, but I would really like the option to add or remove them instead of being able to simply update/change them. The only way to currently fix this is to create a whole new profile? I have seen multiple requests for this across the internet and wanted to make a direct case to the devs. Thanks again for an awesome app!

I have used Bumble on and off for 3 years and I have met quite a few people here but none I would consider a ‚Äúmatch.‚Äù  Like some other reviews, I find this a perfect app for the serial daters. review: This app alienates people who are under the trans/nonbinary/gender diverse umbrella. It is supposed to be revolutionary because only women can message first, and even though you can select a different gender to describe yourself, you still have to choose between only being seen by people who are either looking for ‚Äúmen‚Äù or ‚Äúwomen.‚Äù It means nothing to select a unique gender if it bears no weight on how the app actually filters and categorizes people, and it upholds and enforces a culture that refuses to see us, or take our identities seriously. If your app doesn‚Äôt serve trans women, queer women, nonbinary people, or the slew of other folks alienated by patriarchy and predatory dating app culture, then your app is part of the problem. Trans people are murdered every year, so dating & finding friends is terrifying. This app is complicit in this culture that is already deadly for us. I would give it 0 stars if I could.

I only use the dating feature, though so far not very successfully. Ironically, considering how often women say ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt just say ‚ÄòHey‚Äô‚Äù on Tinder, it‚Äôs exactly what they do on Bumble. Profiles with only pictures and nothing to give a hint at a good conversation opener are everywhere. 

As for the app itself, I swipe left or right on a profile and the same exact profile comes up again right after it, sometimes up to 6 times in a row. I get tired of that and log off, only for this app to send me a notification telling to keep swiping smh. 

Honestly, it‚Äôs enough to make a guy want to give up. If it wasn‚Äôt for that one dude‚Äôs video where he said he failed for a year before finally hitting it off with just one woman, that‚Äôs now his wife, I‚Äôd given up ages ago.

review: The app is pretty easy to use and great for making new friends. I love the idea of having a separate profile just for making friends, that‚Äôs awesome! What I struggle with is on dating, when you match, only the woman can message first. That‚Äôs great and all, but it would be nicer if men could initiate the conversation as well. Considering that I‚Äôm female, it does get old having to message first every single time. Another issue I‚Äôve noticed are guy‚Äôs intentions. This is not the app‚Äôs fault whatsoever, just something to consider. Almost every guy I‚Äôve matched with just wants a one night stand and no serious commitment. (May be different for others) If that‚Äôs not what you‚Äôre looking for, maybe you should think about another app.
title: Both sides should be able to message first

developerResponse: {'id': 9927624, 'body': "We're so sorry you had a bad experience using Coins and interacting with our support team and would love a second chance to turn things around! We're here for you! Send us a message on Facebook or Twitter @BumbleSupport so our team can take another look at your account.", 'modified': '2019-07-30T18:53:00Z'}
review:
The app overall is pretty good. I like how it shares the load of getting a conversation started and I have had much better connections on here than other apps.

One issue I have is when I went to make my first ever purchase of a coin to give someone a SuperSwipe and the app bugged out after I entered my payment info. I tapped the option to use the SuperSwipe, but nothing happened and I could only give a regular swipe.

So now I find it difficult to see your coin balance except for on the purchase screen (and you don't want to accidentally spend them on an option you don't want) so I checked the super boost because it costs 2 coins. Lo and behold, my coin balance is zero!

I received an invoice from Bumble for the coin purchase and I sent them a support ticket explaining what happened. All I got back was an automated response that explained what a SuperSwipe is. Absolutely ridiculous that there is no help on this and after weeks of using the app, the only time I felt a person was worth wasting a couple bucks just to have a mildly better chance at talking apparently is now a completely missed opportunity. To top it all off, I'm still out the $2!

Thanks for the great support, Bumble!
title: Good app, no support

review: I met my boyfriend on bumble without really intending too. I wanted to first just see what was out there and maybe meet someone who wanted what I did in a serious matter. I was looking for more than a fling. I was lucky enough to meet my boyfriend and have been the happiest I could be over the last year. Never thought I would find someone who understands and supports me as well as he does. I truly hope everyone finds their match someday and have as great of a connection as I did! <3 for real bumble thanks for making it an amazing experience with minimal issues. An app that didnt make me feel overwhelmed or completely creeped out.

developerResponse: {'id': 14343721, 'body': "Thanks for taking the time to share your experience! We do offer a premium feature, Bumble, Boost, which lets you view folks who have swiped right on you. You're still able to swipe, match, and message with any possible Admirers for free. If you'd like to chat more about your experience, you can DM us on Facebook or Twitter @BumbleSupport!", 'modified': '2020-03-30T19:56:23Z'}
review:
I hate to use the term ‚Äúscam‚Äù but that‚Äôs exactly what this app is. You can spend hours swiping through every eligible single within your parameters until you receive a message that says to come back later because there are no more potential matches - not a problem.

The issue is when folks do* swipe right on you.

Through extensive use - some paid, some on a free trial - I have come to realize that every time one of these folks who‚Äôve already swiped right on you should come up next in your swiping, their ‚Äúturn‚Äù in your queue, so to speak, and if you do NOT have a subscription, you‚Äôll instead receive an advertisement for Bumble Boost in lieu of their profile.

This is not how it used to work, but IS how it has worked for quite some time now. The short version is: you will never see anyone‚Äôs profile who‚Äôs liked you first no matter how long you swipe unless you pay. Actively removing those profiles from user‚Äôs queue when no paid subscription exists - which, let‚Äôs be clear, is exactly what you‚Äôve done - ESPECIALLY without first notifying users this is how the app functions, is borderline unethical.

Bumble: you should make it clear your app fails to execute its basic purpose if the user has no paid subscription.
title: Bumble Boost: Required

review:
For someone like me, who is very very new to the dating scene, I am genuinely happy that this app exists the way it does. 

In my prior experience with other apps, I have almost always felt anxiety and overwhelmed because there are so many people coming from multiple directions with pick up lines and wanting to meet up within a few lines of conversation. If I can compare that feeling to anything, I‚Äôd compare it to the feeling of being thrown into a back of starving wolves. It‚Äôs overwhelming, anxiety inducing, and scary.

I am very grateful that this dating app exists because I have felt the safest here.
title: No wolves üê∫

developerResponse: {'id': 8007844, 'body': "Thank you for sharing your feedback about how we can improve user profiles and our location feature. We're always working to increase the number of genuine, quality connections for our users so we will definitely pass your input along to our Product Team. We would love to improve your experience! Please email us at feedback@team.bumble.com.", 'modified': '2019-04-01T17:34:11Z'}
review:
[My perspective as a man using this app]

I realIze that the level of detail and customization in other dating apps sometimes causes issues, but the profiles here are so bare that it is, in most cases, impossible to get more than vague, rudimentary hints about a person even if they fully fill out their profile 

This means you basically just have to swipe right on people you find attractive, which is a crappy, unhelpful, and honestly fairly objectifying thing for a supposedly progressive dating app. 

Profiles simply aren‚Äôt detailed enough, and I do not like having to base all my decisions on physical attractiveness or what job someone has. Give us space to write!

Update: others have mentioned this too, so I will chime in. The way this app handles locations is really terrible. I live in a city five miles east of Seattle. If I am at home, 100% of this app‚Äôs matches are in Seattle, most of them between 10 and 15 miles away, despite the fact that there are almost 6 highly populated cities closer than this. If I use the app even 1 mile north of home, it behaves perfectly and suggests people much closer to where I actually live. Your location algorithm is quite awful
title: Profiles are far too simplified

developerResponse: {'id': 32333172, 'body': "We really appreciate you sharing your feedback and we'll be sure sharing it with our Product Team! We know our users are busy so all of our members have the opportunity to extend one match for an additional 24 hours. You can also extend unlimited matches with Bumble Boost and Bumble Premium! To make sure you don't miss any matches, head to your in-app settings to turn on your notifications. üíõ", 'modified': '2022-10-01T12:46:44Z'}
review:
Couple main things that bother me about this app..
For starters, give people more than 24 hours. People work, and don‚Äôt get on the app every day or multiple times a day. This is a missed opportunity for meeting someone.
Also, here I read a profile and think I‚Äôd be interested in someone, get down to their location, and they‚Äôre at an airport within my mile range, but live on the other end of the country. There‚Äôs a reason I put a mileage limit on it, I don‚Äôt want a long distance relationship.
Also, if you travel, (because the app tracks your location), you‚Äôll get people within that mile range no matter where you go, instead of keeping it around where you actually live/will want to have a relationship.
Because of these reasons, this app isn‚Äôt worth using, in my opinion. It‚Äôs a good initial idea, but the people I matched with, I may have missed an opportunity because they weren‚Äôt on every day. Again, people work, have kids to take care of, etc. 
Not everyone prioritizes a dating site. Maybe with some tweaks it will be worth revisiting.
title: Not impressed.

developerResponse: {'id': 33782539, 'body': "Hi there. We're sorry you didn't enjoy your experience on Bumble. review:
I paid for one week of premium, and received no likes or any notifications. The minute after the subscription ended I got notified of 7 likes, with 2 more after another day or two. Bumble is deliberately keeping likes hidden until the subscription ends and then notifying you after the subscription ends - this is absolutely unacceptable and aggravating. And now they‚Äôre limiting the number of likes you can give to an abysmally low number (I can‚Äôt give more than 2-5 likes at a time) and saying it‚Äôs to ‚Äúencourage thoughtful swiping‚Äù, but then they say you can pay to get more likes.
Bumble is seeking to nickel and dime everyone by making its service absolutely unusable, much to the dismay of its users.
If you‚Äôre considering Bumble, just don‚Äôt and get Hinge if you want a useable service.
title: Keeping like behind a paywall

review:
It‚Äôs overall a neat app, but the accidental swipes that are increasingly happening is just getting annoying. Phones are getting bigger these days but my fingers aren‚Äôt. When I scroll up with my left thumb, it flicks out to the side, and Bumble registers this as a left swipe.

I don‚Äôt know about you folks but this means the app design is getting me to pay out of frustration. These accidental swipes only happen when I‚Äôm actually interested in scrolling through someone‚Äôs photos, but after you left swipe, that‚Äôs it, you‚Äôve got to PAY to reroll... so the app loses you the actual matches that ‚Äúcould have been‚Äù

Fix this, please...
title: Sick of the accidental swipes

I tried reinstalling the app, but that didn‚Äôt work either. I notified Customer Service several times. review: I was afraid of online dating, but after several failed relationships that were introduced to me by friends and family, I decided to take matters into my own hands and find the right person. Bumble did just that for me. I got super lucky to have met my now husband on bumble. We met in March 2016, and we got married in September 2018. We have a beautiful little girl and soon our 2nd bumble of joy baby will be arriving. Letting go of my fear of online dating was worth it, going straight to bumble was beyond worth it. I‚Äôm soooo thankful for this app. Been happily married for 2 yrs and madly in love for the past 4 and counting. I highly recommend the app.
title: My life thanks to bumble.

review: After having the same profile for quite awhile, I was recently banned. I cannot imagine what I violated. Bumble won‚Äôt tell me exactly what the complaints were about. I used no profanity, I posted no nudes, not even a shirtless bathroom selfie, and I was never rude to anyone. I was regularly told my profile was one of the better ones out there. My guess is that without mentioning any candidate names, a political shirt I wore in a profile pic is what did it. So, avoid making any political statements in your profiles, or you‚Äôll be banned, too. Tinder is the better app.
title: Profile banned but no reason given.

EDIT1:
See what I mean? The standard Developer‚Äôs Response is to have one of their profile experts help you (you have to have Facebook/Twitter to contact them), but I‚Äôve done this a few times already it‚Äôs pointless... won‚Äôt change the fact that there just aren‚Äôt enough users and the ones that might respond can‚Äôt because they only have 24 hours and people are busy.

review: This app has a feminist idea but its been turned into a platform that benefits men. They swipe right on everyone and then sit back and talk to all the girls who respond.  Leaving you unmatched and feeling confused as to why would they do that if they liked me? Now this isn‚Äôt to sound bitter like ‚Äúoh men don‚Äôt think i‚Äôm pretty‚Äù but it means your chances of finding an actual partner is greatly reduced. I think perhaps limiting the number of likes men can give would greatly help this and make it more balanced so they can‚Äôt go on their like sprees. I have always been considered a very attractive woman -I‚Äôm in my early 20s, great shape, education from a prestigious university and already set in my career and I got no matches. Its not you love, its them. So don‚Äôt get your feelings hurt, I‚Äôve never had a problem getting a date elsewhere and neither will you. This app is completely useless.

But it‚Äôs not.

They limit your potential matches and hide you from other users just like Tinder does, only worse. You will only get matches your first few days unless you pay and most women on here either don‚Äôt message you, are talking to several men at once trying to pick out who will take them on the most expensive date this weekend, or are specifically looking to lead guys on in hopes to be spoiled by them all. The rest seem to want to be apart of the hookup culture without admitting it and a very small percentage want a relationship but usually stay on dating apps after the fact.

I deleted this hookup app after a couple of weeks. Unless you want to pay and/or risk getting played or catching something, for men these apps are trash.

Supposedly you can backtrack to correct a mistake but only after swiping right and left a bunch of times, after you‚Äôve already passed all your best matches. Sometimes I swipe right and have no opportunity to write the person. They just disappear. Sometimes I can‚Äôt decide and then the person disappears before I get a chance to swipe. review: I‚Äôve used Bumble on and off since 2018. While I‚Äôve had the most matches and find more people that I‚Äôm attracted to here than any other app, the paywalls are making it hard to love. You used to be able to swipe as much as you want. Now suddenly I‚Äôve ‚Äúrun out of likes for the day‚Äù..unless, of course, I want to pay. It‚Äôs also incredibly easy to accidentally swipe left but if I want to backtrack, again, I have to pay. And one of the most common complaints that Bumble seems to ignore is the 24 hour timer. I‚Äôve lost tons of matches to expired timers. If you actually want people to meet, then don‚Äôt penalize them for not on the app daily. It seems counterintuitive.

first and foremost, the swiping mechanism is AWFUL. the amount of times ive been scrolling someones profile and accidentally slid my finger a little too far right or too far left is insane. this means im accidentally swiping left on people i want to match with and right on people i dont. the only way to overcome this is to pay a ridiculous amount of money to get rewinds.

developerResponse: {'id': 22403539, 'body': 'Hi there, our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@bumblesupport).', 'modified': '2021-04-22T17:41:55Z'}
review:
The algorithm seems to give you a boost when you first create a profile but then forgets about you after a couple weeks. Living in the second largest city in the US and not getting a single like for a weeks...I‚Äôm not a super model but certainly average and put together, with a fun and appropriate profile. The algorithm seems to be designed to boost your visibility in the beginning so you get likes that you can‚Äôt see without paying extra, and then once you pay it moves on to the next wallet. 

That being said I have met good people using this app but always in the first couple week window, then it seems I have to delete my profile and try again.
title: Only Good at First

review:
I like how Bumble is always updating and adding new features. Covid preferences were a good example and IMO should be highlighted on each profile and only match people with same preferences because not everyone want to meet in real life. 
I like the idea of picking questions to break the ice but only 3 is too low. 
One thing apps couldn‚Äôt solve yet is filtering preferences based on: meet in real life, show me don‚Äôt talk, I‚Äôm bored and looking for someone to chat and cure my boredom or none of them which means I‚Äôm open to explore.
Also having a onboarding surfacing some of these preferences would help to be more assertive with matches. 
Keeping doing the great work. Bumble is a way better than Tinder.
title: Good, not great yet

Really disappointed with the new swipe limit implemented. I have made some good connections on here but it was approximately 1 conversation per 20 swipes. I would even be okay if the swipes would gradually come back on a countdown, but would just prefer unlimited swipes. I read the responses to others complaining and Bumble says ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt need to pay to match‚Äù but putting a limit on swipes and needing to reset it 24 hours kind of makes that untrue in my opinion.

review:
So im a non-binary bisexual, and i have a bone to pick with bumble bff. I am not a woman so why on earth would you require me to be ‚Äúshown to those seeking women‚Äù when BFF is designed for platonic relationships? Youre basically telling me to register as diet woman which is pretty lame imo.

review:
Pros. There are less sex only guys and couples looking for a third. They removed one of the three creeps that harassed me and I appreciated that. The icebreakers often aren‚Äôt great options, but they‚Äôre a great idea. 
 Cons. They didn‚Äôt remove TWO of the three creeps that harassed me, and one of them made me feel very unsafe. 
 You can‚Äôt hide personal contacts like you can with Tinder, and that‚Äôs HUGE. 
You also only have a day to message someone before the option vanishes forever. That, along with the fact that you can‚Äôt hide contacts makes me use this less and less. A few years ago, you could rematch and rewind free, and now that‚Äôs gone.

review: Don‚Äôt get it if your depressed. It will only make you more depressed because it brings clarity to the fact that your not anyone‚Äôs first pick. review: This used to be my favorite dating app. After my account got hacked without my knowledge they banned me. Upon trying to retrieve my account I was informed that I had been banned for actives that went agains community standards. I tried to tell the customer service persons several times that I was hacked and the activity had to be fraudulent they did not care nor would they tell me what was done on my account, under my name,  In the area that I live. review: I love that bumble offers the option to find friends too! I think in todays world with a pandemic and people glued to their phones it‚Äôs hard to make friends now especially as a adult. I get the reason for that function for dating- forces a conversation and not just a empty match that never goes anywhere. But honestly people are busy, people lives and don‚Äôt always have time to check a app daily. Even if bumble bff allowed 48 hours instead of 24 I think that would be better, I just think people are missing out on real friendships possibly because of that feature.
title: BFF

review:
This app needs a ton of work! This is a very basic application that needs to be more intuitive and have fluidity for users. 
You should be able to change your name and also age, in case you misspelled or no longer want to go by your nickname. I do enjoy the quick view profile for people. I also think that the 8.99 for any app with this idea behind it is pretty steep and for just a week of boost (seeing who matched with you) is incredibly ridiculous for an app that needs as much of a overhaul as this one. I can see maybe 1.99 for the week but you should have better membership options with actual bonus highlights for paid customers. It‚Äôs a good idea but still looks to be in its infancy. Charge more when you actually have a product that is worth it
title: Needs work!

review: There is a new ‚Äúgender diversity‚Äù update. So people are now able to choose to further describe their gender. You are given everything from ‚Äúcis man/woman‚Äù to an open text box to fill in whatever you‚Äôd like. After updating your preference, you are asked to update what you are looking for but you are only given 4 choices. Open to everything, Man, women, and non-binary. So as a ‚ÄúCis-woman‚Äù, I would also like to filter my choices down to ‚ÄúCis-men‚Äù, because that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm attracted to. I‚Äôm attracted to genetically XY men. But there is no option for this. My pool will consist of everyone whom identifies as a ‚Äúman‚Äù even if they are XX. If we are going to make an update, make it for every preference. review:
I have used bumble on and off over the years. It **used** to be my preferred dating app because I found the quality of people and conversations were better and I loved that I could select two filters for free to make sure the people in my feed had the most important qualities that I was looking for. 

I recently came back to the app to find that bumble removed ALL of the free filters and wants to charge people to have any kind of control over who they see in their feed!! That is absolutely ridiculous and makes me not want to use Bumble as much because I now have to sift through more people that don‚Äôt have the specific qualities I want. Horrrible update Bumble!!! Bring back the free filter option!!!
title: Removing filters for free users ruining app!!!!!

review: Too many missing features that make other apps easier to use. Taking a second look at profiles that were passed on is a good one. Being able to go back and pass on a profile that you accidentally clicked right on. Having time stamps on all messages. Being able to post a short video to the chat‚Ä¶to name a few. But the biggest issue is profiles that just want penpals or attention‚Ä¶what can you do with the algorithm to weed them out for others unless they are looking for that‚Ä¶For a dating app, a lot of women seem to just want attention online and not to go on dates‚Ä¶The whole point of a dating app is to go on dates‚Ä¶What can you do to push the women that are actually serious about leaving their house to the men that are looking for the same thing‚Ä¶.
title: Missing features

review:
Is it a dating app, a networking app, an app for making friends? It‚Äôs all three, but none. If you are male, you interaction is highly limited. You are constantly asked to feed this thing money to use it, but once you feed it men are limited. Leave this app for women looking for women and go somewhere else. If you have a personality, or a brain this app is not for you. Hands down the worst dating app I‚Äôve ever run across if you are male. Don‚Äôt bother.
Zero stars is not an option it deserves no stars.

If you have no attention span, an IQ of 85 and are devoid of personality, this site is for you. The information about people is so limited and you quickly discover that all un creative knuckleheads have read the same article about how to write a bumble profile. A female friend, who is very attractive told me she got no likes until she put, ‚ÄúI just divorced my rich ex and took him  to the cleaners.‚Äù Then she got hundreds of likes.

The reality is it is designed to make totally uninteresting people look so interesting and interesting people look less than so. It‚Äôs like a dystopian short story by Kurt Vonnegut come to life. 

If you are boring and seek other boring people, you can‚Äôt do better than bumble.
title: Bumble doesn‚Äôt know what it wants to be when it grows up.

developerResponse: {'id': 14100616, 'body': "Thank you for sharing your feedback with us. We're sorry to hear you haven't had a great experience so far. Our team would love to turn this around for you! Please message @bumblesupport on Twitter or Facebook.", 'modified': '2020-03-18T20:07:09Z'}
review:
Bumble shares the same problem as Tinder, plenty of fish etc. There are so many fake profiles that your thumb will get tired of swiping left. Another major problem with these apps are the all the microtransactions to boost your profiles to increase activity, to use the rewind feature and so on. Just another cash grab.

Update:

I paid for a month and my account doesn‚Äôt reflect my paid month. Since support takes 2 days to respond, half my month is gone due to all the exchanges. Such a waste of money.

Update 2:
I paid until Feb. 29 but Bumble support will not reactivate my account because I don‚Äôt have the original receipt that Apple sent me when I renewed my subscription. I have sent support the subscription status showing my subscription doesn‚Äôt expire until February 29 and they wouldn‚Äôt accept that. I then pulled the receipt from Apple that showed I renewed my subscription and they still didn‚Äôt accept it. Absolutely ridiculous. At this point, I‚Äôm so tired of dealing with support that I have accepted the lost. Waste of money and support is even worse.

Bumble, your response to my update is an embarrassment. You should stop the canned response and actually read the response and improve your business model.
title: Another joke

review: I like Bumble, I‚Äôve used it a few times. I paid for the subscription and when I moved from one state to another, had matches in my Beeline from both states. This app is a joke without a punchline. It would be the same price for me to just go out a couple times a month and just engage with people IRL at events or lounges or bars. Then I end up swiping left on them and not getting the chance to know them fully because I didn‚Äôt know they were interested . developerResponse: {'id': 25908520, 'body': "We're disappointed that you feel this way and our Support Team would love to talk with you directly. Our premium features will enhance your experience but we do believe you can form meaningful connections with or without them. Please contact us at https://bumble.com/help-search#contact-us, or on Facebook or Twitter (@bumblesupport) so we can help troubleshoot and improve your experience! We hope to hear from you soon.", 'modified': '2021-10-26T15:17:54Z'}
review:
The platform gets 1 stars because the people on here are classier and the user experience is easy. 

The first negative: 
The algorithm is designed to make money not connections. The second you pay for it, you will get less matches. The app has a ‚ÄúBeeLine‚Äù feature which is a list of people who have liked you before you‚Äôve like them. The issue with Beeline, if you don‚Äôt pay for premium this number only goes up. Which in theory should eventually go down as you swipe. But it doesn‚Äôt indicating this is a pay to match platform. 

The second negative: 
You can purchase ‚ÄúSuperSwipes‚Äù. When you super swipe someone the app advertises that you will be sent to the front of the liked persons list. This is false. On 3 occasions a friend and I tested this feature where one of us super liked the other. On all 3 occasions we never saw each other‚Äôs profile to swipe. This is false advertisement at best. 

I spoke to bumble and they refused to refund any money or give any credit on the app. 

Would not recommend unless you want to spend a lot of money on features that won‚Äôt work in the hopes to get you to spend more money.
title: The algorithm is meant to make money not make connections

developerResponse: {'id': 24780588, 'body': "We're sorry you didn't enjoy your experience on Bumble. Our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@BumbleSupport) and we'd be happy to help.", 'modified': '2021-08-29T10:31:58Z'}
review:
The settings access was only available at the bottom once, when I checked out to navigate what was where.  Then the little profile icon was no longer available, so after I decided I didn‚Äôt want to proceed with this app, I had to delete the app and add it again to delete my profile.
Otherwise, it seems my photo would linger out there on the app, even if I‚Äôm not using it.  That may very well be the case with a lot of the profiles there.
So when the app requires 24 hours for someone to respond to a ‚Äúlike,‚Äù the individual may not even be a current user.
Also, it seemed that the icon to toggle back to the friend search wasn‚Äôt available either after selecting ‚Äúdate.‚Äù

I am a pretty attractive biracial man of colour interested predominately in caucasian women, yet not a single person I have ‚Äúliked‚Äù has ‚Äúliked‚Äù me back‚Ä¶ and I‚Äôve ‚Äúliked‚Äù a plethora of profiles.  

What kills me, are the ‚Äúliberal/progressive‚Äù caucasian women with BLM/social causes in their profiles, yet they can‚Äôt confront their own privilege and racist beliefs enough to match with people of colour; thus, proving themselves more interested in virtue signaling than actually caring about the causes, interests, or emotions of people of colour. review:
I mostly love Bumble. But here's my biggest gripes. Why in the world would you put white text on a yellow background in a messaging app. Do y'all not even care about accessibility? That is a terrible contrast ratio. It's so difficult to read. Why do you only give women 24 hours to respond when there's a match. Women are getting overwhelmed with matches and it's difficult to keep up with the 24 hour timeframe and it doesn't actually feel helpful to anyone but y'all who are trying to convince people to pay you money. 

But seriously... Who is your UX designers? And why did they ever decide to put white text on a yellow background? No really, who are they? I need to talk to them.
title: Mostly love... But WHYYYYY?

26 y/o NYC user here. I pretty much use Hinge exclusively but decided to give Bumble a try. While I get 3-4 matches on Hinge a week, Bumble has been an absolute ghost town. One match in my first week, after devoting a significant amount of time to swiping. Really concerning, especially since NYC is the dating app capital of the US.

I get the feeling that there are A LOT of inactive accounts. Have heard from friends that they still get emails that people are liking their profile even though they deleted the app many months ago. Can‚Äôt really think of a different explanation at this point other than that Bumble is just not where my generation is spending their time. 

A solid interface and concept but Hinge is just more active. Gave it a shot.

The concept is neat but it doesn‚Äôt really make sense.. why would you assume that women can only be friends with other women and can only date men? This has led to me using the dating feature to find more male friends, and then I sometimes get into and awkward pinch when I state in my bio that I only want friends and the men I match with still try to make romantic advances on me. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs a matter of me using the app wrong or if it‚Äôs just not very intuitive. I really wish this was different though.

Toggling with these should help them reappear.", 'modified': '2019-10-31T23:21:29Z'}
review:
Bumble‚Äôs concept is great, in that guys don‚Äôt waste their time messaging a woman who is scared to talk and is only there for her self esteem to get likes because somehow... that‚Äôs a thing.  If you get a message, at least you know she‚Äôs willing to chat.

Bumble still doesn‚Äôt allow you to format your profile in a way that makes you look intelligent.  You either have to use emojis to fill blank lines, or have one huge paragraph. 

And in the most recent update they no longer allow you to see who likes you even if you PAID for access to everything!  And this is where they really lost me.  I was willing to pay for full features, but now they‚Äôre taking those away and I haven‚Äôt seen a refund.   They‚Äôre more into selling ads for events now anyway... so thanks, crooks.
title: Used to be good.

review:
I‚Äôm grateful I found my boyfriend of six months on this app. I never imagined I would find someone like him. 

What I like about this app is that it has the quick features of Tinder with swiping, but provides more detailed profiles like OkCupid. I felt Tinder focused way too much on appearance, and had too few profile details. It‚Äôs nice to know important things like drug use, pets, and religiosity right off the bat, rather than find out fundamental incompatibilities with these topics several dates in. I deleted the app and can‚Äôt remember if another detail is what kind of relationship you‚Äôre looking for (FWB, short-term, long-term), but if it isn‚Äôt, it should be there! OkCupid has more in-depth profiles, but I think it‚Äôs better to not know every personal detail before meeting someone in person.  

I also like the 24 hour rule missing on the other two apps. It‚Äôs great so you‚Äôre not waiting around wondering if someone will ever get back to you. 

Thanks Bumble for helping me find my soulmate!
title: Nice balance of Tinder/OkCupid

developerResponse: {'id': 30508322, 'body': "We really appreciate you sharing your feedback! To make sure you don't miss any matches, head to your in-app settings to turn on your notifications.", 'modified': '2022-06-22T22:42:28Z'}
review:
You know how after you swipe right or someone swipes right on you, that like only last 24 hours then disappears? Here‚Äôs the problem with that, a lot of people don‚Äôt check their bumble everyday, therefore the odds of them seeing it and matching are significantly lower than if likes just stayed in their beeline for as long as possible (hopefully forever), making it incredibly hard to get a match no matter how attractive you are.  
^ that is the reason I would like to see a change be made to solve that problem.
title: Overall on the right track, but there‚Äôs just one problem I‚Äôve found.

developerResponse: {'id': 30158713, 'body': 'We‚Äôre sorry to hear about your experience! We‚Äôre still growing in your area so we‚Äôd recommend expanding your distance range and removing any Advanced Filters for now. Rest assured, new bees are joining the Hive daily so we‚Äôre sure a meaningful connection is just around the corner!', 'modified': '2022-06-04T13:04:00Z'}
review:
In principle I like Bumble for the women message first feature. It‚Äôs a much friendlier app than Tinder and there seem to be more people looking for serious relationships on Bumble. But if you live in certain rural areas, the distance feature can be a real issue. 

I live in a location that does not seem to have a high population of people on the app, or at least people I‚Äôm interested in. I happen to be about 3 hours away from two urban areas, one to the east and one to the west, were I presume I could find people I‚Äôm interested in and would be within a distance I could meet up with regularly. 

These areas aren‚Äôt within 100 miles of where I live, but the next option for distance beyond 99 miles is ‚Äúthe whole country.‚Äù But when I set it to the whole country, these two urban areas, the closest to me, get skipped over and I only see people who are from other states and much, much further away.

This is extremely frustrating and frankly an issue I‚Äôve had with a few apps. But I know people are on this app in these cities because I‚Äôve lived in them previously and used Bumble.
title: Distance is a problem

developerResponse: {'id': 30156003, 'body': "Hi there. We hate to hear you didn't get what you were looking for from our Support Team. We would be more than happy to take a closer look at this for you. Send us a message at: bumble.com/contact.", 'modified': '2022-06-04T07:57:24Z'}
review:
I was using and enjoying the app for several months until it forced me to choose from 1 of 3 causes to support with no option to choose a cause of my own or opt out. I believe forcing anyone with your agenda is fundamentally wrong, regardless of the agenda and even if I agree with one one of the options. I can‚Äôt even get into my profile without selecting an option, so I just deleted the app.

Update: I received a response from the developer that I could opt out; however, I made attempts to do so (before writing the review) with no success. The selection process popped up whenever the app was opened and the only way to proceed was to select a cause. I don‚Äôt know if this has changed, but it‚Äôs soured my opinion of Bumble, so I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll download it again to try.
title: Forces their beliefs on users

developerResponse: {'id': 29986567, 'body': "Hi HamsterJuice. We're sorry you didn't enjoy your experience on Bumble. Our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@BumbleSupport) and we'd be happy to help.", 'modified': '2022-05-26T14:19:16Z'}
review:
I've used this app two separate times a few years apart. The first time, finding matches was relatively easy and consistent and I met some really great people. I entered a relationship with one of them for a couple years and deleted the app.

A few months ago I redownloaded Bumble and Hinge. My experience with Bumble this time around has been pretty abysmal. The very first day there was an influx of likes, and in the weeks since I've received around 5 total. Compare this with Hinge, where likes are more direct than a simple right swipe, yet I receive them on a daily basis. I use the same photos on both apps; the only difference is the apps themselves.

That influx of likes you get your first day on Bumble seems very manipulative considering your profile will likely not receive that kind of attention ever again. They try to get you hooked with an initial burst of likes, and then they start pushing their absurdly priced premium features. It's embarrassingly transparent.

If you're serious about making quality connections, Bumble is unfortunately no longer the place to do it. Your time and energy are better spent elsewhere.
title: Arbitrary algorithm with overpriced premium "features"

Change it back.

developerResponse: {'id': 22333749, 'body': 'Hi there, our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@bumblesupport).', 'modified': '2021-04-19T18:05:30Z'}
review:
To start, I‚Äôm a female. To be honest with you, I hated the way the app made the women make the first move. 

Here‚Äôs why, the person I ended up connecting with couldn‚Äôt even talk to me, cause I never saw their profile.
If you do not have premium, you can not see guys who liked you. Instead, you get a line up of a random pick of guys to swipe through.

So I decided to get premium, and I‚Äôm not trying to sound funny or arrogant in any way AT ALL, but I‚Äôm a pretty good looking woman...
 Tinders premium gave me 100‚Äôs of likes a day, yet I was only receiving 3 guys who ‚Äòliked‚Äô my profile in a day on bumble. 
I‚Äôm sorry, but that doesn‚Äôt make sense. 

Even on premium, the algorithm doesn‚Äôt work in your favor.
 
Good thing I had put my snap hashtag in my bio when I made the profile. I kinda figured that if a guy REALLY wanted to talk to me, he would contact me in any way he could. 

Honestly, Ladies, you can really benefit from just throwing your snap/insta out there, it could save you money. I paid for the premium, and still didn‚Äôt meet anyone that way.
 It‚Äôs good to build up the confidence as a woman to approach first, but it‚Äôs also nice having a way for someone to contact you first.
title: I think I met the one!

review:
The prompts they give you are aimed at the specific mentality they advertise for- withdrawn and opinionated. 

The profile is laid out in an itemized fashion like an o-miai, but without the convenient arranged meeting after a match. The questions they give you to express yourself are geared towards individuals who want to say something without saying anything.

 Example: Beaches or mountains? 

At first blush one might think these profile-filler things would do a lot of work for you, but for anybody looking for a casual interaction it‚Äôs too pedantic and for those looking for something serious it‚Äôs pure frippery.

You should not try this app unless you want to meet people trying to come out of their shell through it. All but the very young has been either up their own [business] or loaded down with stuff a habitual tech user wouldn‚Äôt be capable of handling.

Perhaps your personal mileage might differ- I hope as much- but don‚Äôt expect your next life partner to come from this. At best, a new drinking partner. 

Try the free trial thing right off the bat. If it doesn‚Äôt work out, just try striking up conversation with strangers irl. You‚Äôll have better conversations on average, regardless of where it goes.
title: Like any other, but encourages bad sentiments

developerResponse: {'id': 6219788, 'body': 'Hi Scott! The safety of our users is our upmost priority so our platform does not limit the amount of users that you can block or report. We know our bees are busy which is why you have the option to expand the 24-hour time limit to respond with one match every day. We would love to improve your time on Bumble. Please DM us on Twitter or Facebook!', 'modified': '2018-12-03T16:54:36Z'}
review:
It‚Äôs all about money on this app.  And a waste of money considering the other options.  

The app developers place a 24 hour time table for replies without really considering facts of life.  Such as Illness, educational exams, military deployments, vacations, travel outside of the country, failure of WiFi services to cellular service due to (ie: weather, changing of cellular services). Or just taking flights that many do which can take one out of the ability for nearly a month due to international plans.   Basically to place a time table on any reply is a failure on the apps part.  

Then the fact that your not able anyone you wish.  Or have a unlimited number of blocks.  From those that may Co-Workers issues, ex‚Äôs, and so forth.   

In the short time I have had this app in trying to give it a chance.  

My concern also stems to the reply to justify the cost.  The developers failed to obtain a reasonable amount of paid ads to help shoulder the cost.  

Apps such as Grindr became large because they learned that to get end users you also had to work within the community and realize a few things.  Including to sale the product to investors and get out of the way.
title: App

I believe they populate this app with fake users probably digging through Facebook profiles and creating fake accounts to make it seem like there‚Äôs more people but there‚Äôs no reason why out of 500 swypes not even a single match! Impossible.... even after they tricked me into subscribing 50$ which is non refundable by accidentally clicking the free trial and no updates on when it would expire.. I believe it‚Äôs a scam model to Mis inform people and take they‚Äôre money after forgetting they signed up for the trial.
